results.description:
Drinking Skeptically is an informal social event designed to promote fellowship and networking among skeptics, critical-thinkers, and like-minded individuals. Drinking Skeptically provides an opportunity for skeptics to talk, share ideas (and yes, drink) in a casual, relaxed atmosphere. We discuss the issues of the day and whatever else is on our minds. But most of all, we have fun while promoting skepticism, science, and rationality. Don't drink? Don't let that stop you from joining us! Some of the world's most famous skeptics are teetotallers, and we are happy to have you! Remember that drinking skeptically means drinking responsibly. If there's one thing science has taught us, it's the effects of alcohol on the human body. To learn more about Drinking Skeptically see www.drinkingskeptically.org

The area set aside be the establishment for our group is not wheelchair accessible. The venue has no age restriction for the duration of our event.

CFI-DC encourages people with disabilities to participate in its programs and activities. If you anticipate needing accommodations or have questions about physical access you may email sdavis [at] centerforinquiry [dot] net in advance of the event.

results.description:
The Baltimore BENG Networking meeting is held the second Thursday of each month at 6:30 pm.


Will you be joining us?


BENG is the perfect outlet to provide you with:

• employment information,

• opportunities for networking,

• emotional support, and

tools to accelerate your job search.

The Baltimore chapter of the Business Executives Networking Group (BENG) is a multidiscipline, independent group of job seekers, those currently employed and business networkers, who are willing to help others. Current membership includes mid to senior level executives with over ten (10) years of business experience. Past attendees have come from the financial management, information technology, legal, manufacturing, engineering, transportation, logistics, distribution and general management industries. We actively seek new members from all disciplines.

MEETING GUIDELINES

Each attendee will get a chance to deliver their two-minute elevator speech, share recent successes and failures, present their networking requests, discuss their job search questions and any concerns they may be struggling with, and apprise the group of any new searches, requests, etc. that they have become aware of.

Please bring at least fifteen copies of your "one pager". This should provide your contact information at the top, followed by a brief overview of your background, and finally your target company list and a list of people you would like to meet. They should be handed out to the attendees just before you make your presentation, thus helping them to provide you with targeted assistance and advice.

Please have copies of your resume available to handout to those interested parties who may want to learn more about you or pass it on to individuals they think may be interested in talking to you. Also, bring a nametag to wear and a "name" tent card to place on the table in front of you.

Our objective is to give each member an opportunity to continually hone their networking skills, meet their peers from various disciplines, share job leads and develop networking opportunities.

Attire is business casual.
results.name: Join Us for the Monthly BENG Meeting

Each year Philanthropik supports the valiant efforts of the Ronald McDonald House locally, to share and spread joy to sick and shut in children during the holiday season when they are most vulnerable and away from home + resources. results.description:
A Salon of Creatives, Artists, and Thinkers, without booze. Come and talk large words and great ideas. Artistic and Political Movements. Religious, Spirituals, Humanists, Atheists, Deists, go at. Discuss, have conversations. Speak and listen. Please don't spend time speaking about your sobriety, we have plenty of places to talk about that. This is where to talk about books, the art you are working on, how you are making the world a better place, the painting you saw at that place, why X is the correct opinion/option with regard to Y, what you are curious about, the new album by ________, what you are trying to figure out, what your latest software project is doing, the fantastic show that really made you think, how your painting is going, how to solve writer's or other's block, your big idea, etc.

Potluck dinner, I'll bring vegan beans and veggies concoction, paper plates and bowels, plastic utensils, napkins, foam cups (if you want to be environmentally conscious, bring your own and these won't be used by you), coffee maker, cappuccino maker, and hot pot (someone should bring good ground coffee and good tea). Food should be able to be eaten when standing, for we shall stand and talk and move about from person to person, group to group.

Someone should organize the potluck portion of this so we don't get all vegetables and no deserts or ground coffee. Please step up and I'll set up links for you.

No booze, etc, and don't be under the influence when you arrive.
results.name: Conversational Salon and Potluck

With your continued dedication and attendance, you will uncover and better understand YOUR specific gifts and how to receive and inter[ret them as well as overcome pre-conceived notions that may be holding you back.

This class is a progressive way to develop your psychic abilities and heighten your experiences and perceptive reading ability through meditation. Some of the most famous mediums and channelers were trained in this method. It is designed to attract those who wish to transform their lives; to uncover skills, techniques and a new way of looking at things.

Through this, you will learn to relieve daily stress, heal yourself at a soul level, and promote balance, harmony, clarity and focus in your everyday life. The purpose of the exercises is to stimulate and challenge you to step beyond your current limitations.

For beginners and the experienced. Move at your own pace with the support and heightened sensitivities of the group environment.

Please, call to apply so we may discuss your intention to attend. The synchronicity of the energies of the group as well as the consistency of attendance aids in the group’s cohesiveness, trust and growth.

This ASL BRIDGE meetup is every two weeks on Thursday evening from 7 to 9 p.m.

This meet up will meet at Panera Bread
8541 Georgia Ave. the corner of Colesville Rd.
Silver Spring, MD --

Parking & Metro
The nearest parking garage:
Town Square Garage, 801 Ellsworth Dr. (NE) and it is free after 6:00 pm.

Silver Spring Metro Station - Red line stop at Colesville Rd.

www.silverspringdowntown.com has a good map of where are Panera Bread and the garage.


As Evelyn Leonard is no longer hosting this meetup- this meet up now has

TWO Co-hosts JOEL  (2nd THURS. )  & KEVIN (4th THURS) of each month

I am trying a new format for this meetup:

This format for the 2nd Thursday ONLY:

Each session should be divided into two groups. Each signer determines where they fit:

1st group: Fingerspelling & Flashcard and ASL books - in one group  (beginning/novice signers)

2nd group: Intermediate-Advanced/conversational (no talking, sign only)

Each person determines what there level is. As you make the transition to the second group-- please respect my one rule and be committed to really practicing ASL without using your voice. signing only.  The more you depend on your receptive skills, the more you will learn.

PLEASE INVITE YOUR DEAF FRIENDS, FAMILY and COLLEAGUES TO JOIN US!

THANKS,

JOEL and KEVIN

WELCOME TO PATUXENT TOASTMASTERS

The mission of the Patuxent Toastmasters Club is to provide a mutually supportive and positive learning environment in which every member has the opportunity to develop both communication and leadership skills, which in turn foster self-confidence and personal growth.

Toastmasters International has awarded PATUXENT TOASTMASTERS with the PRESIDENT'S DISTINGUISHED CLUB AWARD for club excellence in 2012/2013.

___________________________________________________

Humorous Speech and Evaluation Contest!!!!!

Patuxent Toastmasters Club presents its much anticipated annual Humorous Speech and Evaluation Contest on September 12, 2013 at 7:30 PM.  All club members in good standing are eligible to compete.  Guests are very welcome for this special event.

Are you looking for ways to write a humorous speech?  Look no further than the article below the holiday photo.

____________________________________________________

Patuxent Toastmasters Club meets on the 2nd and 4th Thursdays of every month. Regular meetings start promptly at 7:30 PM at the historic Oliver's Carriage House in downtown Columbia.

Oliver's Carriage house is located at 5410 Leaf Treader Way, Columbia, MD.

MAP

All are welcome.  Our club offers a diverse learning environment.  We have members from many different walks of life, ethnicities, religions and nationalities.  Although we meet in a community church, our club has no religious affiliations.

Holiday 2012 Club photo

How to Add Humor to Any Speech

by Joe Cooke, ACB

Listeners appreciate a little humor, even in a serious speech. Done incorrectly, humor can be a disaster. Executed correctly, humor lightens the load, eases the burden and releases tension. There are three basic methods for adding humor to a speech: Tell a canned joke, tell an original joke or simply make a wry observation.


Method #1: Canned Jokes
The beauty of a canned joke is that it has usually withstood the test of time. For someone just starting to add humor, this is the best technique. By telling an old standby, you can concentrate on timing and delivery – two of the major keys to being funny. 

Timing and Delivery: This refers to the way you present a joke. These two ideas may be the most important aspects of humor. As Toastmasters, we know that communication is more than just words. When you deliver a joke, your attitude alone can make or break the punch line. 

But you have to get over the idea that you have to be perfect. Your audience wants you to succeed, and they want to laugh. 

One of our newer members served as Toastmaster for the first time. She opened with a joke, stumbling through it. Even though she had to read the joke and even apologized to us ahead of time for her lack of experience, she told the joke with a smile and a wink. We laughed! 


“Audacity and an air of confidence can overcome your worst fears."


Audacity and an air of confidence can overcome your worst fears. Just say to yourself, “Okay, I’m terrified. I might botch the punch line, I might forget the entire joke; maybe no one will laugh. But I’m going to do it anyway. It will be hard this first time, but easier the next and the next and the next.” 

The basic keys to adding humor to your speech are:

relevance, and

unexpected insight

Let’s say you were doing a talk about ESPN or sports fanatics or even just sports in general. You might try the following “used” joke: 

“A sports-buff showed up at the sold-out football game. He took his seat on the 50-yard line and then gently placed a woman’s coat and an extra ticket on the seat next to him. The spectator behind him asked, “Are you saving that seat for someone?” 

The man said, “No. It would have been for my wife, but she’s passed on.” 

“Oh, I’m so sorry to hear that,” the spectator said. Then he added, “Gosh, why didn’t you give that extra ticket to a friend?” 

The man turned around with a surprised look on his face and said, “All my friends are at the funeral.”

This joke is obviously relevant to a sports-oriented talk. It sets the theme of the speech and warms up the audience. 

The insight is that we sometimes get so wrapped up in our own stuff that we forget about other people. We all do it. This guy just did it bigger and that makes it funny. 

Try out this joke (or any other) on several friends. Practice timing the punch line. Try different wording to make it your own. Try out different pacing, pausing in various places for emphasis. Like any other skill, you learn to tell a joke by practicing. Most people who claim they don’t know any jokes are simply saying that they haven’t practiced any. 

Most canned jokes are generic and you don’t have to attribute your source. However, if you are relating something specific to a certain comedian, you should give proper credit. Use your best judgment. You may want to say something like, “As Steve Martin so aptly put it: ‘The new phone book is here! The new phone book is here!’” But don’t start your joke with “I got this off the Internet...” Just launch into it. 

Once you become comfortable telling jokes you’ve found from other sources, take your humor up a notch by trying out some original material. 

Method #2: New Material
There is a basic three-point structure you can follow to create your own, original material:

Come up with a topic,

Add a premise, and

Turn it around.

Here’s how it works: First, come up with a topic. For example, if you are a parent, you might want to make a joke about being a father or a mother. Here’s a caveat. If you are a woman, don’t choose the topic of being a father. The audience won’t be able to relate through you. 


“Sometimes a witty observation will produce no more
than a smile or a twinkle in someone’s eye. That’s enough."


Next, create a premise. Let’s say you are making a joke about being a dad. Your premise might be that it’s hard to be a dad. Or, that having kids makes men a bit stupid. Or weird. Or that having kids is scary. 

Comedy trainer Judy Carter uses those four specific words when she is training people to be funny. She calls them “attitude” words. When you are just beginning to experiment with writing your own material, it is best to stick with the basics:

Algebra homework is hard.

Skateboarding on the highway is stupid.

Being a dad is weird.

Being tall around toddlers is scary.

The third part is the hard part. You have to bring in the unexpected. For instance, if you are working with “skateboarding on the highway is stupid,” and you were being serious, you might finish with how dangerous it is. For a joke, look for insight. Look for pain. 

Now, let’s look at a concrete example:

Step one: Choose a topic. Let’s say you chose “parenting.”

Step two: Choose an attitude. For example, “raising kids is hard.”

Step three: Create a twist. First of all, what is hard about raising kids?

Maybe your answer is that you have to be more mature. 

Now, think of a way to twist that around to surprise the audience. Here is how I used this topic to open my speech on traveling. 

“Traveling with kids is hard! You gotta be tough, you know? 

We just got back from Disney World. We spent all day walking and it was hot and it was like, ‘I need a drink of water, and ‘I’m tired,’ and ‘I need to go potty.’ 

Finally, my six-year old put her hands on her hips and said, ‘Dad, quit whining.’”

Timing and Delivery, Part II. Practice makes perfect. Although great material always sounds like it is impromptu, it rarely is. With jokes, more than with anything else, practice is imperative. You have to practice until it sounds as if you are just making it up on the spot. 

Record your joke delivery and then listen. After a while, you will get a good feel for the pace. You will hear where the pauses work and where they don’t. Along the way, you’ll memorize the joke. It will also stop sounding funny to you. Don’t worry; your audience has never heard it. 

In my travelogue about Florida, I tell a story about my five-year old. 

“Kids are wise, aren’t they? My five-year old son played in the sprinklers at the park and on the ride back to our condo, he took off all his clothes. He got out of the car and everyone stared at him as he walked down the street, naked as can be. JoAnn and I were mortified, of course, but he just looked around and said, ‘Well, at least I’m wearing sun block!’”

This story stopped being funny to me a long time ago, but whenever I tell it, everyone guffaws. 

The Rule of Three
Three is an inherently funny number. Just make a list of three things. Throw out the last one and replace it with something outlandish. A word, a phrase. A dead fish. 

Let’s take the simple topic of sun block and play it out. 

“Sun block is weird. (notice the attitude word) My wife packs SPF 44. Sun protection factor 44. Do you know what that means? That means that we can stay out in the sun 44 times longer with it on. Where are we going anyway? The Mojave Desert? The Sahara? The planet Mercury?”

Acting Out
Take your humor up another notch...act it out. Now take your rant against sun block and play it out even further: 

“Have you ever noticed that the companies that make sun block make bug repellent too? You have to have both because they make the sun block smell like Piña Coladas. Of course it’s going to attract bugs. They’re like ‘Yeah baby! It’s cocktail hour!’”

Surviving the Joke
If you’ve practiced your jokes and bounced them off the right people ahead of time, you’re sure to get some laughs. Even so, the day will come when the audience just doesn’t get it. There are two ways to deal with the “bomb:” 

One is the “saver.” Powerhouse speaker J.R. Ridinger sometimes gets going so fast and furious that he leaves the audience behind. His favorite saver: “Maybe that one will catch you on the way home.” 

The other technique is to just keep on keeping on. One of my all-time favorite inspirational speakers once gave a sermon on sex. The funny quotes she told at the beginning left the audience speechless. She handled her choice of material like a true professional, never missing a beat, though I squirmed and turned a bit red. 
Listening to this professional also showed me how confidence and audacity can pull off a joke that a less confident person could never get away with. 


Method #3: Wry Observations
Clothes make the man. Naked people have little or no influence on society. – Mark Twain 

One of the great masters of the witty statements, Mark Twain once said that electric lights were to humor as lightning was to wit. In other words, unlike a joke that has a story-line, natural wit usually comes out as a pointed, wry observation. 

Use the triple-A method to develop your ability to make witty statements. First, be Aware, then add Attitude and Allow yourself to grow. 

Be aware by understanding that humor comes from understanding shared experiences, especially painful ones. In order to fully cultivate your own sense of humor, you have to stop seeing your life as completely tragic. We all have troubles. Open your eyes and your mind and watch for the irony and the contrast in life. 

Your attitude will help you be funny. Watch any great comedian, male or female. Some are gutsy and loud, some are meek and shy. You have to develop an attitude that fits you and then you have to let it shine. 

“You have to develop an attitude that fits you and then you have to let it shine."


Finally, allow yourself to be funny. Open your mouth and try. Toastmasters is the perfect place to nurture your inner comic. Occasionally you may tell a stinker. Get over it and try again. Progress only comes with practice in front of real people. 

You don’t have to elicit a roar of laughter from your audience. Sometimes a witty observation will produce no more than a smile or a twinkle in someone’s eye. 

That’s enough. 

Remember that Toastmasters is a learning organization. Give yourself permission to try, and trust that your fellow members are either (a) wishing they were as brave as you and respecting you for it, (b) about in the same 

place on the progress curve as you are and respecting you for it, or (c) re-living the time they first tried humor and respecting you for doing the same. 

Now, get out there. Be yourself, be happy and be confident. Long after your listeners have forgotten the content of your speech, they will still remember how you made them feel.

results.description:
**NOTE:  PLEASE BRING ADEQUATE WATER FOR YOUR DOG!**

Friday will be 60 degrees with 4 mph wind.  Sunshine!  No percent chance of rain!  Yay!  It's a perfect day for a long walk around the lake.

Please NOTE that this is NOT the main entrance to Lake Centennial Park.  To get to the West Entrance, you must turn ONTO CENTENNIAL LANE from Highway 108, then go about .40 mile, then take the first RIGHT into the parking lot of the WEST ENTRANCE, and drive all the way to the back of the parking lot to Pavillion "O".  That's where we will meet, at the trail head.  The roads from one entrance to the other do NOT connect inside the park, so you must get to this entrance by Centennial Lane.

Please arrive early, to allow the dogs time to sniff and form their pack. We will leave on time -  If you can't make it please change your RSVP promptly, or leave a comment. We'll turn to the right on the trail so you'll know where to find us if you arrive late.  [In fact if you're really late (by several minutes) you may wish to turn left so you'll run into us and we can walk together at least part of the route.]  


There may be joggers and bikers coming through.  Please call out "On your left!" when you see them coming from either direction so we can clear our dogs from the path.

Please bring water for your dogs.  We'll have drinking stops and take pictures at a couple of places, and we'll all have fun!


Columbia Dogs on the Go provides a way for friendly people with friendly dogs to meet people with similar interests on a voluntary basis. By replying "Yes" to this RSVP and attending this event, you acknowledge that:


•  You are responsible for your own safety and the safety of your dogs and any guests. 

•  Your dogs are current on their vaccinations.

•  Your dogs will be kept on a leash (non-retractable) and under your control at the Meetup.

•  You will clean up after your dogs at the Meetup.

•  You will update your RSVP if your plans change.

•  You understand that the Meetup ends when the walk ends. (If you choose to meet other members at a restaurant, dog park, or other location, it is on your own time and not part of the Meetup event.)

 Looking forward to seeing everyone again!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the gaggle of dogs by the pavillion.

results.description:
Lords and Ladies of the realm, we have been invited by the King to his castle for a great feast, where his finest soldiers and entertainers will provide fantastic spectacles and wonderment!

Several people have mentioned they've never been to Medieval Times, or haven't been in some time, so I thought it would be fun for everyone to experience it together; especially since weekends will be less fun as the weather gets colder.

If you're not familiar with Medieval Times, it's a two-hour dinner and entertainment show set in Medieval Spain, featuring jousting, falconry, and horse demonstrations along a main storyline. The storyline, featuring 6 knights, changes depending on the loudest section, so bring your outside voice! There's also a small museum featuring some historical replicas and other displays of medieval life, if you're into that sort of thing.

I know this is a relatively big spend, but I do have TEN discount tickets available for the folks who jump on it quickly ($35 + tax/gratuity). I may be able to get more.

In the event that we get 15 people or more committed by late October, we can get a Group discount ~$37/person (+ tax/gratuity. Why the extra $2, I didn't ask). They'll treat us a bit better, at least, since we will have to pay in advance. If there's enough interest, I'll get more concrete info on what the benefits are.

Also, I mentioned the dinner earlier - for the herbivores among us, they DO have a vegetarian meal. Both meals are listed on their site.
results.name: Medieval Times Dinner and Tournament!

results.description:
Mary Thompson, research historian at Mount Vernon, will open a window into the Christmas holiday traditions that the Washington’s shared with their family and guests, as well as what life was like for staff and slaves during  the busy holiday season. Traditional foods, hospitality, and decorations will be a focus of the lecture. Samples of holiday dishes the Washingtons served will be available.

Mary V. Thompson is a Research Historian at The Fred W. Smith National Library for the Study of George Washington with extensive experience I documenting foodways of the colonial period. She is currently the Research Historian at Mount Vernon, with a primary focus on everyday life on the estate, including domestic routines, foodways, religious practices, slavery, and the slave community. More recently, Mary authored the book In the Hands of a Good Providence: Religion in the Life of George Washington (Charlottesville: University of Virginia Press, 2008), for which she received the 2009 Alexandria History Award from the Alexandria [Virginia] Historical Society. Mary is currently putting the finishing touches on a book focused on slave life at Mount Vernon.
results.name: Christmas Traditions at Mount Vernon in the 18th Century

results.description:
Next Baltimore plant-based support group / potluck will be on the second Friday of the month, as always, at 6:30 pm as always, same location.  

This month, we’ll talk about how to cope with emotional eating and food as addiction.   Just about everyone experiences emotional eating and losing control over hyper-palatable food for the wrong reasons.   We’ll talk about some strategies, and find out what works, or isn’t working for us, and what the experts have to say about it.  

There will be an opportunity to get more help, either by pairing up for phone support, or getting regular phone support from one of the organizers.   

We’ll show an excerpt of the excellent presentation “Breaking the Food Seduction” by Neal Barnard, M.D. of the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine.   

We will also discuss PCRM 21 day vegan kickstart challenge that we will run starting on January 1st. Participants would register for the challenge on PCRM website, http://www.pcrm.org/health/diets/kickstart/kickstart-programs, and then experiment with recipes for a 2-3 weeks before starting the program on January 1st, 2016 along with other participants and with assistance of the group leadership and coaches, if needed. We will announce official meetup for the 21 Day Kick start soon!

And as always we’ll have a Registered Dietitian, and a Medical Doctor, on hand.    
Please bring a dish that has no animal products (no meat, poultry, fish, dairy, butter, eggs), and not too much, if any, salt, sugar or oil.  

Keep an eye out for our twice-monthly conference calls, always at 6:30 pm, either on the Third Thursday of the month, or the Fourth Tuesday,
Conference dial-in number:    [masked] 
Participant access code:  [masked]    

Check this Meetup-site to look for any last-minute or holiday schedule changes. This is for everyone including people who have never been to an in-person meeting.  We'll give practical advice about how we prepare food, overcome challenges, and we'll share recipes.  

For the in-person meetings, it's OK to bring a fruit salad or just a salad if that's easier for you.  If it would be a burden to bring something, COME ANYWAY.  Most likely we'll have plenty to eat if most people bring something.    

A list of ingredients with your food item is required, for anyone with food sensitivities or preferences.  

A new feature is that we are asking people to write down the recipe of each dish, along with your name and the name of the dish, since this is allows people to make the dish at home after they’ve tried it.  

We’ll raffle off a special prize; the raffle is open to (1) people who bring in the recipe of their dish, and (2) people who are attending for the first, second or third time, regardless of whether they brought a dish.   

We'll have the usual discussion, information, support, tips & tricks, and Q & A, 

No judgement, proceed at your own pace, enjoy the journey, and try new recipes often!   Please bring friend and spread the word.  Please RSVP here if you can (not mandatory, but please do if you might be able to make it).  Can't wait to see you there!

The Nutrition As Medicine Team
results.name: How to deal with emotional eating & food addictions and  21 day vegan kickstart

results.description:
This is a joint event posted between Baltimore Nightlife Group / Baltimore Newbies and the Charm City Social Club. It's an open event with NO COVER CHARGE, so feel free to bring a friend! Come one come all to a very merry Meetup!

The holidays are rapidly approaching, so of course it's only right that we get together to enjoy a little holiday cheer, BNG style! This year's Holiday Jingle Ball Meet and Greet will be at Pratt Street Ale House in their Cantina Bar. Anyone who joined us last year will tell you that this is a great bar, with excellent food and top notch drinks!

The theme is holiday festive, so feel free to bring your holiday accessories and outfits. We'll have prizes for most festive outfit! If you're new to the BNG, this is a great opportunity to come out and meet your new friends! If you're a veteran, or even if you've only been to a handful of events before, this Meet and Greet is for you, too! Come out and help us show Pratt Street why our group members are the greatest in all of Baltimore!

~ Drink and food specials ~

$4 Select Oliver Ales

$5 Rail Drinks

$5 Santa's Little Helper Shots (Bailey's based shooter)

$6 House Wine

$6 Jingle Juice (vodka based mixed drink)

$7 Buffalo Bites or Cheese Nachos

~ Parking ~

The closest parking is in the Arrow garage located on Lombard St. adjacent to the Days Inn, behind Pratt Street Ale House. ***Please check the garage closing time and make sure it fits your plans before parking in any downtown parking garage***

You may also use Uber, Lyft, the Circulator, a good old fashion taxi, or carpool with a friend! Whatever your plans are, please plan for responsible transportation home.

We look forward to seeing you all there!

~ Your Organizers ~

results.description:
FRIDAYS from 7-8pm: restorative yoga
SATURDAYS from 8:30-9:30am: heated vinyasa
$15 for a single drop-in class; $80 for a 10-class pack
Sign-up online: http://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/ws?studioid=176740&stype=-7 Studies show that yoga offers countless mental and physical health benefits: reducing insomnia, combating depression, stress management and relaxation, improved concentration and focus, lowering blood pressure and blood sugar associated with diabetes, improved strength and flexibility, stretching tight or stiff muscles and joints and so much more.
Please wear comfortable clothing that you don't mind sweating in and bring a yoga mat if you have one (we will have loaner mats available if you don't), a towel and water.
Never done yoga before or a beginner? Flexibility is not required. We absolutely WELCOME and ENCOURAGE you to attend. As long as you're breathing, you CAN do yoga. These FREE classes are tailored for all ages and fitness levels. Come with an OPEN mind and heart and be READY to have fun!!! Any questions? Please email them to: [masked] or call[masked]-5434. See you soon!

results.description:
Join Nancy Andrews for a meditation to welcome the New Moon! In astrology, the New Moon is the moment when the old passes away and the new is ushered in. It is a powerful time for sending out your prayer, wishes, desires to the Universe! At the end of the meditation, Nancy will give everyone a personal message!

Investment: $15

------------------------------------------------------
Nancy is a Certified Crystal Healer and Energy Worker. She is also both a Usui Reiki Master and Ama Deus Healing Practitioner and has received attunements to a diverse array of healing modalities. Nancy is currently offering Intuitive Guidance and Healing sessions at Inspired Journeys. Her nine years of intensive study in spirituality and metaphysics have given her the tools to help clients gently work through their emotional and spiritual blocks. Nancy uses Oracle cards, crystals, music and sound, aromatherapy, healing touch and her own intuition to provide the best healing and spiritual guidance in each session. Nancy believes her calling in life is to assist others on their path of self-discovery and enlightenment and ease the body and mind through transitional periods in life. Every session is personalized for the needs of each client.

results.description:
UPDATE: The Church will provide meat and stuffing for this event.  Please bring a side dish, dessert, or drinks (soda or juice).  Thank you!

Singles Mixer - Pot Luck Dinner - Redemption House Life Center - Glen Burnie

Bring a potluck dish to share. A potluck dish is a substantial main dish, salad or side/dessert item. Walking distance from the church (in the shopping center next to the church), there is a Food Lion grocery store if you need to pick up an item to contribute to the potluck.  Redemption House does not have a way to keep things warm or cold, so crock pots are awesome to bring. A commercial kitchen is coming soon.

Where: Redemption House Life Center, 7489 Baltimore-Annapolis Boulevard, Glen Burnie, MD 21061.  When: the second Friday of each month at 7:00pm

Background: Redemption House Life Center (RHLC) is a great, dynamic, young church in the heart of Glen Burnie. I met the pastors, David and Tracy Whittington. They are wonderful people committed to the Great Commission, helping the needy, and being a joyous, loving influence in their community. Check out their website: http://www.rhlc.us/

Parking: At RHLC you can park near the front door of the church at 7489 Baltimore-Annapolis Boulevard (along the street or in the free parking garage across the street). There is also a parking lot at the church's rear door, at 133 Delaware Avenue, Glen Burnie: this is the most convenient option - park near the rear door and enter the church through the rear door.


Contact Jeff or Charles with questions and suggestions: If you are interested in the church's food ministry, please ask Jeff or me for more information.  Please email me through this meetup site and/or call me to let me know if you have any questions or suggestions. I will be at this organizational meeting - so please come help - and bring a friend! Thank you!


-Charles

results.description:
Still have openings for two more players. Send me an email at [masked] if you're interested in joining us.

Just began the Jade Regent adventure path. Here's a synopsis of the adventure:

In the Jade Regent Adventure Path, PCs will travel epic distances with a crew of lively NPCs, starting in the familiar nation of Varisia and ending up on the other side of the world. As a result, the primary element you should keep in mind when creating your character is the fact that while the Adventure Path begins in Sandpoint, it won’t stay there—build your character as someone eager to leave this quiet town to seek adventure elsewhere in the world and you’ll be set! This guide’s purpose is to help players create and equip their characters so they can readily take on the challenges and trials they will face along the journey to a different continent. In addition to spoiler-free details pertaining to the types of areas PCs are most likely to encounter on their legendary voyage, this guide will provide campaign traits to f lesh out characters’ backgrounds, advice on races and classes, and rules regarding their relationships with important NPCs and the caravan they’ll be traveling with.

results.description:
Please remember to rsvp if you intend to come and if you find you can not attend to change that rsvp to a no. We choose  trails in various locations to give people in different areas a chance to make it to a hike. On the other hand if we see no one is coming we generally decide to hike the trails closest to us or with other groups we belong to rather then driving a distance or hiking alone so please be update your rsvp if it changes.

Please remember to rsvp with how many dogs you will be bringing so we are sure to not go over 10 dogs.

The terrain we will be sticking to this time will be easy with little to no hills with a steady but not overly fast pace.


Perfect trails for introducing new dogs to the group.  Most the trails are wide, so walking with a leashed pup as they are introduced to the group won't be a problem.

Yes we cancel if it rains or other inclement unsafe weather condition arise. I wait as long as possible to cancel in hopes of giving the weather time to clear up. If you  need more then an hours notice please let me know so I can get on the site and cancel early enough for you check it and know prior heading out for the hike. You can also text my cell phone if you are unsure the day of the hike and I will let you know if we need to cancel do to weather. The best thing is to be sure and give me your number as well as taking mine so if something happens such as an unforeseen emergency just prior an event that would prevent either of us from attending we can contact one another. Here is my number again just in case you didn't see it above[masked]

As always remember leashes, poop bags, water for you and your pup and proper hiking gear such as water proof boots. Most all trails have water or in some cases wet or muddy terrain to deal with.

It's a looped hike so please be prepared to carry any dog packages you have to clean up after since we most likely won't be retracing our steps.

Sometimes the trail itself is busy so please be prepared to bring your dog to a heal by your side if we come across others out enjoying the trails. This is our rule for every dog. Small dogs, big dogs, calm dogs, rowdy dogs. It doesn't matter our group always shows good polite doggie manners when coming across others on the trails(even if those we meet don't do the same).
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the subaru outback with JMS... Just Making Smiles logo on windows.443-851-0784

results.description:
The Maryland Food Bank needs an accurate estimate of how many people will be volunteering for this event, so please update your RSVP as soon as possible if you aren't able to make it to this event.

=======================================


IMPORTANT VOLUNTEER INFO:

Open-toe shoes are PROHIBITED at the warehouse.  Wear clothes that you don't mind getting dirty (which probably won't happen, but it's a possibility).

Please arrive to the warehouse ON TIME.  We can't begin until EVERYONE is at the warehouse.

Additional volunteer info can be found at the MD Food Bank's website, at www.mdfoodbank.org.


=======================================

The Maryland Food Bank was founded in 1979 to coordinate the procurement and distribution of food donations from manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers and government agencies to organizations providing free food to the state's hungry.

Volunteers usually work on a high-tech conveyor belt in the warehouse, pulling specific types of food from the belt as they pass, and packing the sorted food into 25 - 50-pound boxes. Full boxes are then placed on the Maryland Food Bank's daily menu, available for more than 600 soup kitchens, pantries and shelters across the state to order.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the volunteer meeting area, which is on the left side of the lobby.
results.name: Maryland Food Bank

Habitat for Humanity ReStores are nonprofit home improvement stores and donation centers that sell new and gently used furniture, home accessories, building materials, and appliances to the public at a fraction of the retail price. Habitat for Humanity ReStores are proudly owned and operated by local Habitat for Humanity affiliates, and proceeds are used to build homes, communities, and hope locally and around the world.

results.description:
I put in  Soapstone and Bull Run, but I'm open to changes if the group want them. 

These trails are technical and challenging with several steep climbs, rocks, roots, loose dirt and uneven surfaces. To make up for all of the hard stuff there is also a good amount of flat and downhill sections. We’ll also be sharing the trails with mountain bikers, hikers and other runners. The distance will be[masked] miles total, or about an hour.

Trail Description: 
The Soapstone trail is about 3 miles, out and back. It has several hills and climbs, creek crossings, and a bit of asphalt running. Most of the trail is wooded and there are bathrooms and water fountains min-way. There will be some water crossings, dirt and muddy areas, rocks and sticks so…please wear shoes you don’t mind getting dirty or wet. We can also hit the Bull run trail for 1 extra mile. 
Parking: 
Parking is available at the Park and ride in Catonsville (intersection of Rolling Road/MD 166 and 195) or at the trail head, look for the group of runners. 
Hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: We will be near the trail head just off the road.
results.name: Trail Run at your own pace-Patapsco Soapstone and Bull Run Trail (Catonsville)

Refresh and rejuvenate with a free community service initiative to introduce people to breathing & meditation techniques that have a calming effect on the mind and reduce stress. In this 60-minute interactive session, participants develop insight on how to reduce negative emotions - anger, regret, sadness, anxiety and fear - that eat up our energy and time putting an unnecessary burden on our efforts. This workshop is also an introduction to the Art of Living Course.

During the workshop participants will experience:


• Breathing techniques that increase energy and vitality


• A guided meditation


• The connection between our breath, emotions, mind, body & the Self


• Discussion about the tendencies of the mind

Participants will be introduced to tools to chart a new course to healthier, happier, stress-free living.

results.description:
Come join us on December 12th as we are planning to hold hold several sessions and challenges for kids of all ages and abilities, followed by a demo day where the kids can see great and fun examples of how professionals use technology in the real world. 


The First Hour - Will include several challenges, with those completing their challenge receiving a certificate of completion from Coder Dojo Annapolis


Those new to coding will be challenged to complete one or more challenges in Minecraft or Star Wars with several challenges designed for more experienced coders in Scratch and more advanced programming languages. 

The Second Hour - Will include a series of live demos where the kids can walk around, visit with  and learn more about new technologies that are used by technology professionals in the real world. 

Interested in setting up a table to demo? Let us know! 

CoderDojo is a free, volunteer-led, community based programming club for young people between 7 and 17, where they can  learn how to code, develop websites, apps, programs, games and explore technology in an informal and creative environment.

** Please note that by reserving a ticket, you agree to the terms and conditions at the end of this description. 

FAQ

Do I need a laptop? No, but while we will have several laptops available to borrow, we do encourage kids who have access to a laptop to come with their own.


Does a parent need to be present?We encourage all parents to be involved and be present at all sessions. For children 12 years and under, a parent MUST stay in the room at all times. The parent may choose to participate in the session or not. For children 13 and above, the parent can choose to leave but it should be understood that we are in no way liable or responsible for your child.

Who are the mentors? Our mentors are adults working in various tech fields, educators and university students. We have a number of mentors and volunteers who have stepped up, but more are always needed and welcome (older kids are welcome to join and help as well - great on a resume!)

We look forward to seeing many of you. If you have any questions, please contact David Blackburn at[masked] or Dave Gilinson at [masked]

=======================

IMPORTANT NOTICE 
======================= 

TERMS AND CONDITIONS  


LEGALESE VERSION (borrowed and adapted from other CoderDojos):


MENTORS AND TECHNOLOGY: I have been made fully aware and understand that:

• All CoderDojo mentors are offering their services voluntarily in their individual capacity. The host venue bears no formal relationship, responsibility or liability whatsoever in connection with the CoderDojo organizers or mentors and is offering its facilities to the CoderDojo Annapolis on a discretionary and good faith basis.

• All CoderDojo mentors are offering their services voluntarily and on a good faith, not-for profit, basis. Neither the CoderDojo mentors nor the host venue bear any responsibly or liability whatsoever or howsowever arising, for any loss or damage, whether direct or indirect, arising from any advice or instruction, or lack of advice or instruction, offered by any CoderDojo mentor.

• We are participating in this workshop on a fully voluntary basis and do so at our own risk. We are free to follow or not to follow the CoderDojo mentors’ advice as we decide. Neither the host venue nor the CoderDojo mentors bear any responsibly for any damage that may be caused as a result of their instruction or lack of instruction.

For example, if our laptop crashes or is damaged due to the downloading of any particular software suggested by a CoderDojo mentor, then we, and only we, bear full responsibility for any such damage and we hereby hold harmless and indemnify the host venue and the CoderDojo mentors and organizers for and against any claim for damages howsoever arising.

PHOTOGRAPHY: I understand that CoderDojo volunteers and news agencies may from time to time take photos or video of the CoderDojo sessions to be published for editorial or promotional purposes. If I do not want my child photographed, I understand that I need to make this known to the organizers at the beginning of the session. They will try to ensure that I am notified before any photography or videotaping for publication begins so I may remove my child during that time.

RESPONSIBILITY FOR PARTICIPANTS: Each child must be accompanied by an adult who signs in for him / her and is responsible for him / her during the session; this adult must stay for the entire session, no exceptions are permitted.

By RSVPing for CoderDojo Annapolis on Meetup.com, I consent to participating in the CoderDojo workshop on this basis.

results.description:
Welcome to Warrior Meditation! These meditation sessions are secular and available to anyone wishing to meditate. All experience levels are welcome. During this session, I'll be offering 4 rounds of 10 to 15 minutes of Shamatha Meditation (also known as Calm Abiding, or Mindfulness meditation). If you are new to meditation and you would like to discuss the technique one on one, please send me a message, and we can schedule time before meditation to go over the technique. After the meditation session we discuss the meditation experience, and also take in select readings from a variety of meditation masters. The focus on most of our reading sessions is about using what we learn in meditation in every day life situations. 

Cheers!

Terri
results.name: Calm Abiding Meditation (also known as "Mindfulness meditation"

results.description:
Toastmasters International is a nonprofit educational organization that operates clubs worldwide for the purpose of helping members improve their communication, public, and leadership skills. Through its thousands of member clubs, Toastmasters International offers a program of communication and leadership projects designed to help people learn the arts of speaking, listening, and thinking.

Especially in our club (Wh”Y” Not Toastmasters) in Ellicott City we thrive towards not only those but also leadership skills and be the best in the area to help the community and club members. Our goal is to be in the friendly competition with other clubs and also to be better than “former ourselves”.

Every day we grow better and every meeting we do it better – that is our mission! We are having a party for the holidays in December following our 12th December (Saturday) meeting at 10:30 am. Our goal is to finish 10 minutes early at 11:50 AM and start our fun, food and learn part at noon to 1:00 pm on that day.

We encourage you to bring your best attitude, best holiday dress, best friend and best simile for a prosperous Holiday & New Year’s party and more so help bring together a diversified group of thriving individual who are always ready to learn and spread the knowledge to the community.  

“Only a life lived IN the service of others IS worth living.” – Albert Einstein.

Please let us know if you need anything from us – but we want you to enjoy and help us grow as a community and help us grow our club for better speakers, leaders and givers. Come and join us in Glen Mar Church, Ellicott City.
results.how_to_find_us: When you enter Glen Mar United Methodist Church, please go down to the first floor.  Our meeting is in room 145.

results.description:
**NOTE:  Please BRING WATER for your dogs!** 

Saturday will be 59 degrees at 11:00 a.m. and only 5% chance of rain.  We never get tired of this walk.  We will START at Hopewell Park, follow the trail leading to Lake Elkhorn, walk all the way around it, then walk through the neighborhood forest back to the start point at the pool. It's 3 miles, all paved, flat (except for gentle slopes) and stroller friendly.

Hopewell Park is accessible from Snowden River Parkway after you pass by Carved Stone/Starbuck's on the left (as you are approaching from Broken Land Parkway.)  It is a left turn onto Rustling Leaf.  Look for "Hopewell Pool" sign. The pool is the second right; turn in and park there.  We will meet by the trail.  (Click the link above to "Hopewell Park" to view a map.)  Note:  Please be able to walk at 2.5 miles/hour and be willing to keep up with the pack in order to complete the walk in the allotted time.

Please arrive a little early so the dogs can sniff & form a pack.  We will leave on time.

------------------------------------------------------------

Columbia Dogs on the Go provides a way for you to meet friendly people with Friendly Dogs on a voluntary basis. By replying "Yes" to this RSVP and attending this event, you acknowledge that:

•  You are responsible for your own safety and the safety of your dogs and any guests.

•  Your dogs are current on their vaccinations.

•  Your dogs will be kept on a leash (non-retractable) and under your control at the Meetup.

•  You will clean up after your dogs at the Meetup.

•  You will update your RSVP if your plans change.

•  You understand that the Meetup ends when the walk ends. (If you choose to meet other members at a restaurant, dog park, or other location, it is on your own time and not part of the Meetup event.)
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet in the parking lot for the swimming pool.
results.name: Hopewell Park to Lake Elkhorn 3 miles

results.description:
One of the world’s great gardens, Longwood’s story is one of legacy, innovation, and stewardship. Our  Gardens are a living expression of all that our founder, Pierre S. du Pont, found inspiring, meaningful, and beautiful. From the intricate fountain systems  to the meticulous gardens to the architectural grandeur, awe-inspiring discoveries await at every turn.

www.longwoodgardens.org

The price is $27 per ticket.  You must buy tickets WELL in advance.  Click on tickets link and then choose A Long Wood Christmas, then choose timed event.  CHOOSE THE 2 PM ENTRY.  IF THAT IS SOLD OUT THEN CHOSE THE 2:30 ENTRY

******** Please don't wait until you get there to buy tickets, because they will be sold out. ********

We will stay until 8 pm, so that we can see the gardens and conservatory during the day and when it is dark take in the SPECTACULAR HOLIDAY LIGHTS that blanket the grounds.  That will get us back to Annapolis Mall  approximately 10:00 pm

The drive is 1 hr, 45 minutes, assuming no traffic back-ups.  WE ARE WORKING ON NEW MEETING PLACES TO CAR POOL.  PLEASE READ COMMENTS!!!!  We cannot be late, so please arrive by 11:30 am for carpooling. Parking is free at Longwood Gardens, but it can take a while to get in line.

Link to meeting place at the Annapolis Mall:  http://www.meetup.com/Active-Annapolitans/messages/boards/thread/47648482

There are places where food/dinner can be purchased at various price points.  Cannot bring your own food into the gardens.

Frequently asked questions:  http://longwoodgardens.org/visit/frequently-asked-questions
results.name: Longwood Gardens

results.description:
Let's gather to celebrate the Holiday Season and participate in Duckpin Bowling; a classic and festive pastime of Baltimorians!  

Mustang Alley's Bowling & Bistro in Little Italy puts a hip spin on bowling!  Check out their website http://www.mustangalleys.com/.

Anyone can play, no experience is required!  Duckpin is just like regular bowling but with a smaller ball and smaller pins.  Unfortunately ugly bowling shoes are still required. :)


Logistics:

The cost is $25 to RSVP and includes our reserved bowling lanes as well as a selection of hors d'oeuvres set up just for our group!

We have 4 lanes reserved from Noon to 3pm.  Bowling will be from 12:30-2:30.  


Prefer a local beer or cocktail with your bowling? Mustang Alley's offers a full cash bar!


Please RSVP by December 1st so we can have an accurate head count before ordering our food.  Thank you!


Ugly Christmas Sweater:


To encourage the Holiday spirit please feel free to wear your favorite ugly Christmas sweater!  Don't have one? Maybe check out your local thrift store OR if you are crafty you can make one!  Guys, don't forget about any ugly Christmas ties you may own.  :)


For those who participate we'll hold a contest and vote on the ugliest sweater and/or tie.  The winner will get some sort of prize!


Location & Parking:


Mustang Alley’s is located on the corner of South Central and Bank Street on the second floor of the Holland Tack Manufacturing Company. Their entrance is on Bank Street through the double glass doors.

Street parking throughout Little Italy is free for up to 3 hours.


The Little Italy Parking Garage is $4 for the day and is located at 400 South Central Ave, a one minute walk from Mustang Alley's (just across from the Tack Factory on Central Ave).


The metered parking on Central Ave directly in front of the Tack Factory is only good for 2 hours.

Feel free to message me with any questions, hope to see you there!
results.name: Duckpin Bowling & Ugly Christmas Sweater Party in Little Italy!!!

results.description:
Okay, so Chuck was being completely realistic when he scheduled a hike instead of a paddle... past years proved to be way too cold to have this as a paddle and so, this year he scheduled a hike around Annapolis instead. Well, IT TURNS OUT THAT, the forecast for Saturday is looking quite warm with the forecast being: Partly sunny, with a high near 61.

Chuck is committed to doing the hike, but I'm hosting a 10'ish mile paddle from Truxton Park across the Severn and Whitehall Bay to Hackett Point where we'll find a sandy beach for a break and then we'll paddle back. We will likely do some exploring somewhere in between.

We will time our paddle so that we can get off the water and packed up in time to drive into Annapolis to see the light show with the rest of the crew.

We will be on the water at 12:00, so please show up no later than 11:30 so that you're ready to leave at 12:00.
Sunset is at 4:45, so this should be plenty of time to do the 10 miles and be off before dark.

COLD WATER GEAR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS PADDLE. To learn more about what that specifically entails click this link: http://www.meetup.com/Chesapeake-Kayak-Adventures/messages/boards/thread/38728872.
results.name: Go For a Paddle, and THEN go to the Annapolis Christmas Lighted Boat Parade

results.description:
A vision board is collage representing things you would like to attract to your life. You can cut pictures and phrases out of magazines, print images from websites, and include your own photos in the collage. You glue the images and words onto a piece of poster board and place it somewhere you can see it on a regular basis (mine is hanging on the bulletin board in my spare bedroom). Then you sit back and wait for the magic to happen! A vision board party is a fun way to create the life that you want for yourself.

It will be hosted by our very own diva Danielle Crawley who is by the way a CERTIFIED LIFE COACH.

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/whats-your-vision-tickets-8457880749

Please pay on Event Brite as soon as possible.  In order for this event to take place we will need a minimum amount of people in attendance.  Thanks.

results.description:
The weather on Saturday is forecast to be mostly sunny and mild with a high in the low 60's. Let's take advantage of this fine December weather to enjoy a walk around Quiet Waters Park prior to the Eastport Christmas Lights Boat Parade. I've posted the Eastport boat parade as a separate SHR event starting at 4:30 pm at the Boatyard Bar & Grill. That's where I'll be heading after this Quiet Waters nature walk event.

http://www.meetup.com/Second-Half-Rally-Active-Recreation-for-Fun-People/events/223811178/

Meetup Spot and Parking

Quiet Waters Park is a convenient place to go walking in a peaceful natural environment. The park has excellent facilities and is well-laid out with paved trails, picnic pavilions, open fields, water views, and a visitors center that's modern, clean, and comfortable. 

Our group will meet at the large gazebo behind the Quiet Waters Park entrance sign. From there we can walk into the park for FREE to enjoy its amenities. Ample parking is available just across Hillsmere Drive in the Bay Ridge Shopping Plaza. 

Walking Around Quiet Waters Park

This walk is approximately five miles on the paved trails surrounding the edge of the park. Most of the trails are framed by impressive large trees and thick woods. Our route will also pass several open areas, the seasonal ice skating pond, a dog park, and some beautiful waterfront facing the South River. There's a nice visitors center mid-route where food and real restrooms are available.

The pace will be easygoing to enjoy the park's natural beauty while getting a bit of exercise. The entire route is basically a big loop with side trails that brings us back to the park entrance. Total time to circle the park and see everything should be about three hours or so.

Final Details

We'll need good walking weather for this event. A little rain won't stop us, but we won't go in miserable conditions. I'll post an update and send out an email by 10:00 am if we need to change plans or cancel. Call Jake at[masked] to find us. I can't always answer my phone at events, but you can try.

I hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the Gazebo by the Quiet Waters Park entrance sign
results.name: Pre-Parade Trail Walk at Quiet Waters Park

results.name: Santa Bar Crawl

results.description:
Annapolis Christmas Lighted Boat Parade and Hike

 The Annapolis Christmas Lighted Boat Parade has proved for the last 4 years to be a pretty good time and the lights on the boats were pretty neat.  Yes my guess is that we will not be doing as much paddling by this time of year so I am scheduling a hiking event.  If the weather ends up being nice we'll have a paddle on Sunday.  Somehow this event always manages to take me out of my Bah Humbug, Scrooge like attitude towards the holidays into something that more appropriately reflects the spirit of the season.

We will again this year be following a self guided hike/walk through Annapolis sponsored by the American Volkssport Association that starts from the parking lot at the Eastpoint Shopping Center.

We will be doing the 10 K (6 Mile) hike and leaving the parking lot at 1:30 PM which should allow for a somewhat leisurely pace and a stop for coffee and a little shopping before returning to the parking lot around 5:00 PM.  If you're not up for a 6 mile walk, Annapolis isn't the kind of place where you should have too much trouble killing a couple hours before meeting us back at the Eastport Shopping Center around 5:00 PM.

After the hike we will walk from Eastport to the 6th Street Brigdge to watch the Annapolis Christmas Lighted Boat Parade.  After the parade we'll get in our cars and drive to a restaurant somewhere away from downtown Annapolis where it will be much easier to get tables for a larger group.  Everything about the day is optional.  Skip the hike and show up for the rest or any combination of the above that you want to put together.

results.description:
Gaelle has been dancing since she could walk, she began studying ballet, Jazz, and tap at the conservatory of Longjumeau which is located in France. At the age of 18, Gaelle was among the few to be selected as part of a dance group called “TILENZ’S”. As part of "TILENZ'S" she was able to perform dance routines for artists and events across France and all throughout Europe. Her passion for music and dance allowed her to excel in the dance world. 
An extraordinary dancer, Gaelle has performed and choreographed songs with Koffi Olomide, Papa Wemba, Elizio, Samy Diko, Dr Sakis, Noyau Dur, Jessy El Matador, La Selesao, Stella Mouna, Marquis (band group), Janelia, Bebey Bass, Becky Umeh, and other Afro-Caribbean superstars to name a few. She was given the title of "Queen of Dancehall" in Paris on 2006. She also has won dance battles in Paris such as Hip-Hop music Howard (Dancehall category).


Gaelle moved to the United States from Paris to pursue her education in 2009 and her career in dance. She is originally is from the Caribbean Island of  “Martinique where the lively spirit of the people can be found through dance.

Gaelle has been teaching dance in the United States since 2011 in diverse dance studios such as Rumbero, Princess Moon, and Dance at Dupont Circle, dance studios and has recently obtained a Zumba License (2014) to expand on her love for chorography and dance.

She will introduce dance forms from Democratic Republic of Congo, Cote d'Ivoire, Jamaica and the West Indies.

Students will learn the basic technique and movement for N'dombolo, Soukous, Coupé décalé, Mapouka, Zouk and Ragga/Dancehall. Also will gain confidence to perform dances in social settings, clubs, street dances and on stage while increasing physical fitness. RSVP for your  dance class and look at our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/groups/AfroCaribbeanDance/?fref=ts

results.description:
This is a cool (actually cold) outdoor event in Eastport that our SHR group has done for the past three years. It's always fun being outside in the dark by Spa Creek on a dock watching the brightly lighted boat parade. The passing boats in the parade are creatively decorated and the spectators are in a holiday mood. People who attend are generally filled with seasonal excitement and spirit(s).

Christmas Lights Boat Parade

The Christmas Lights Boat Parade is sponsored by the Eastport Yacht Club, which describes it as follows:

Every year on the second Saturday in December, magic happens on the water of the Annapolis Harbor... Boats suddenly appear out of the cold winter night illuminated with thousands of colored lights and crewed by jolly revelers. Families and friends gather at their favorite viewing spots along the waterfront to see this yearly spectacle and to celebrate the holiday season together. The Eastport Yacht Club Lights Parade is one of Annapolis' signature events, and we invite you to join us as a participant or a spectator cheering on all the decorated boats and their crews.

Full details and the parade viewing map are here:

http://www.eastportyc.org/index.php/welcome-parade-lights

Meet at the Boatyard Bar & Grill

The boat parade runs from 6-8 pm, so we'll first gather at 4:30 pm in the Boatyard bar to share some Christmas cheer and refreshments. It's a fun casual place that's conveniently located just two blocks away from a good viewing area on Spa Creek. Parking is available on neighborhood streets.

Full details and location of the Boatyard Bar & Grill are available on Yelp:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-boatyard-bar-and-grill-annapolis

Viewing the Boat Parade

Around 5:45 pm, our group will head over to the dock area near the Annapolis Canoe & Kayak store and the Chart House restaurant. Follow Severn Ave. to 3rd Street at the ACK store and walk along the Spa Creek docks toward the Chart House. There are several long piers there where people gather to watch the parade. We'll look for a good space with a nice view of Spa Creek and the passing boats.If you miss us at the Boatyard Bar & Grill, look for us there.

The annual Eastport boat parade is a festive event that's a nice way to celebrate the Christmas holiday season. Call Jake at[masked] to find us. I can't always answer my phone at events, but you can try.

I hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Jake's neon white hair in the bar area at Boatyard Grill
results.name: Christmas Lights Boat Parade on Spa Creek in Annapolis

results.description:
PRESENCE HEALING SESSIONS with Gene Ang, Ph.D.

Dr. Gene Ang will be holding energy healing sessions based on a number of cutting-edge healing modalities. Each session can be tailored made for each client. You may request the type of modality you desire or Gene can make a recommendation.  
3 slots available only and must be scheduled in advance: 6pm, 7pm, or 8pm
http://www.geneang.com/www.geneang.com/Presence_Healing.html

Description of Healing Modalities:

Arcturian Healing Light (AHL) is Gene’s own healing modality inspired by Higher Beings from the star system Arcturus as a form of Divine healing. The purpose of AHL is to reawaken one’s Soul purpose in life and to dissolve any of the blockages (physical, emotional, mental, or spiritual) to the awareness and manifestation of that purpose. (1 hour: $250)

Dimensional Analysis and Balancing (DAB) allows the client and Gene to look at any issue (illness, person, organ, relationship, business etc...) and energetically diagnose what dimension and specifically up to 12 subdivisions on that dimension that issue needs balancing.  The second part of the session then provides energetic and vibrational healing to center and balance those affected dimensions (1 hour: $250 or 2 hour option: $500)

The Reconnection® is best suited for people who want a quantum shift and acceleration forward in their life purpose. 2 separate sessions, spaced a day apart, are required. (1 hour; 2 consecutive sessions; total cost $333) http://www.thereconnection.com/

Gene Ang has also been trained in the following modalities: Access Bars®, Vortex Healing®, Divine Healing, Matrix Energetix®, Pranic HEaling®, Quantum Healing Hypnosis®, Reconnective Healing®, and Shamanic Healing. ($250)


December 12, Saturday: 6pm, 7pm, 8pm only
Must be scheduled and payments made in advance.
 Afternoon slots are full. 


Please contact Nourishing Journey to choose your time slot at [masked] or call (410) 992-3001.  Online payment:
http://nourishing-journey.com/journey/event-registration/

Please do not rsvp for this meetup instead call to make an appointment.

The above healing modalities are not meant to replace conventional medicine and advice from your personal physician. Gene Ang is not a medical doctor and makes no claims, promises or guarantees, and is neither diagnosing nor treating specific health issues or challenges. These modalities should be used in conjunction with regular medical care.


Gene Ang, Ph.D. has a healing practice based in Thousand Oaks, California and sees clients for Reconnective Healing, the Reconnection, Pranic Healing, Vortex Healing, and Shamanic Healing. In addition, he teaches a number of seminars that focus on the integration of science, spirituality, and healing. Gene travels around the United States facilitating healing sessions and workshops.

Gene received his BA from Stanford in Human Biology and Philosophy/Religious Studies, and was formally trained as a Neurobiologist at Yale where he earned his doctorate in basic mechanisms of how the brain develops followed by a post-doctoral fellowship on how ultrasound can affect the developing cerebral cortex.

After his post-doctoral fellowship, Gene decided to step into the role of a facilitator of healing in order to directly interact with helping people.

Most of his work centers around the use of subtle energy to help align the subtle energy body, its channels, meridians, and energy centers to help restore balance and harmony so that healing can occur whether it be physical, emotional, mental, and/or spiritual.

Gene doesn't see himself as the healer but simply as part of the interconnectedness that occurs when facilitator, client, and Source/Love/God interact to bring healing forth. He sees his teaching engagements and seminars as an extension of this interaction that occurs on multiple dimensions to bring wholeness and understanding to all involved.

Website: www.geneang.com
results.how_to_find_us: Enter Dunkin Donut Driveway.
results.name: PRESENCE HEALING SESSIONS with Gene Ang, Ph.D.

Bring your prayers and intentions.  We encourage you to bring you drums or other percussion instruments.  If you don't have any, we have plenty to share. 

A drum circle is a fun experience that is accessible to anyone who wants to participate regardless of age or experience level. The goal is to achieve oneness with a group, not rhythmic perfection. Shamanism is the oldest spiritual belief system on earth. Drumming has been a method of group healing and achieving unity since the beginning of time. Studies have shown that drumming accelerates physical healing, boosts the immune system and produces feelings of well-being.

The drum circle will be held every 2nd Saturday of the month from 7:00 to 8:30 with time for socializing afterwards. 

A $10 donation would be appreciated. No one will be turned away if finances are an issue. All are welcome.

A drum circle is a fun experience that is accessible to anyone who wants to participate regardless of age or experience level. The goal is to achieve oneness with a group, not rhythmic perfection. Shamanism is the oldest spiritual belief system on earth. Drumming has been a method of group healing and achieving unity since the beginning of time. Studies have shown that drumming accelerates physical healing, boosts the immune system and produces feelings of well-being.

The drum circle will be held every 2nd Saturday of the month from 7:00 to 8:30 with time for socializing afterwards.

A $10 donation would be appreciated. No one will be turned away if finances are an issue. All are welcome.

results.description:
Disclaimer: Mountain biking is a risky sport, By signing up for this meetup you are agreeing you have seen, read, and understand our waiver located here:http://www.meetup.com/MVD-Mountain-Bikers/pages/Standard_Waiver_for_Meetup_Rides/


This ride is strictly intermediate terrain including log overs, rocks, stream crossings, very steep climbs and in general pretty technical. It's not the water shed, but it is demanding. Please understand this is an intermediate ride due to this terrain, and distance.

Where/Directions: Rockburn Branch Park, East Side (Landing Road entrance).  Come into the park, follow the road all the way to the end where you will see a turn around circle.  We will meet here.  

What time: Meet between 8:45 and 9:00 AM at parking lot. Wheels rolling by 9:00am.  This will be a very long ride, so be there on time and ready to roll.

Pace: Pace will be approx. 7-9 mph moving average (some of the climbs I'll be as slow as 3 mph, just a warning). Please note people tend to lose about 1 mph average in Patapsco as compared to Rosaryville, or Fairland. These paces are appropriate for most average riders who have good cardio endurance, but not for beginners, due to terrain and mileage. Attitude is laid-back and friendly. This is a no-drop ride, i.e., we wait up for everyone at intersections, but as it is a long ride, we will only wait as long as the last person needs to catch a breath. 

Terrain: Ranges from Easy to Difficult. Most trails are in great shape, but some sections may be loose and/or soft, i.e., plan on some mud spots. There are a few steep/long climbs, rocks and technical sections, and a stream crossing or two. A couple of sections may be a hike-a-bike for some. There are also active road sections (about 5-7 miles worth). This is a friendly ride, so we will wait up for everyone, just be advised that the terrain can be somewhat difficult in places. This video of Patapsco represents most of the area we will hit:0

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i0aXny9lKbg

Distance/Route: Approx. 28 miles, give or take a few.  We will start in Rockburn, head into Avalon via Morning Choice, and then climb up and through the Catonsville side, then some road riding, followed by a little bit of Banneker, then hitting the Trolley Trail in Old Ecity, and back on single track up and around Devils horns, then back roads through old Ecity, back to Avalon, and finally up and back to Rockburn.  Exact route may change depending on group dynamics, trail conditions, etc., but there are no real bail points on this ride. Please understand this will be a demanding ride.  Only about 6 miles are fairly flat, everything else is up and down. Please also note we will be climbing about 3,200 feet in elevation. This is the anticipated route:  Rockburn/Ptap/Banneker/Old Ecity roads/Back ride

Duration: Ride time: approx. 4 hours if we average 7 mph the entire ride; total time: approx. 4.5 to 5 hours due to this being a no drop group ride, and planned breaks. Total time will really depend on group dynamics, trail conditions, wait-ups, mechanicals and/or number of stops. As mentioned, no-drop, which may add to total time.  We will also take at least one 15 minute break to refuel.


Bring: Helmet (required), water (as much as you can carry, but we will have a chance to refill at around 6 miles, 9 miles, and 23 miles), spare tube/patch kit, pump/CO2, multi-tool, I.D., emergency contact info where it can be easily located on your person, food (fuel)and a good attitude, as this ride is as much about camaraderie as it is about riding. Take a look at your bike and make sure it is in good working condition (Ptap will take its toll on the bike). Please note, you need enough water / fluids to go from mile 9 to 23, that's 24 miles without a place to get water.  Please be prepared.

Weather: Shine Only (there will undoubtedly be some mud, but no ride if it’s raining or the trails are too muddy). Protect our trails and don’t ride them when they’re fragile.

Ride Organizer(s): Craig

Craig P, 4four3-eight4five-3six8nine
results.how_to_find_us: Drive all the way to the end of the paved road.  We will meet at the turn around circle.  Look for Green Ram and me on my Stumpy.
results.name: Patapsco/Banneker/O­ld Ecity/MTB Ride (with a little road)

results.description:
Please remember to rsvp if you intend to come and if you find you can not attend to change that rsvp to a no. We choose  trails in various locations to give people in different areas a chance to make it to a hike. On the other hand if we see no one is coming we generally decide to hike the trails closest to us or with other groups we belong to rather then driving a distance or hiking alone so please be update your rsvp if it changes. Please remember to rsvp with how many dogs you will be bringing so we are sure to not go over 10 dogs.


*This hike...

 There are plenty of options for making varying distances and terrain difficultly. The paths we will be sticking to will be pretty much a flat terrain. We will hike continually but not at fast pace. This is a great place for dogs to enjoy nature on wide clean paths(for the most part). Terrific for practicing leashed heal commands as a group. There are facilities at the Park office.  The terrain is mostly easy to medium but with some steep hills to hike if the group chooses to do some exploring on their own after the easy hike.  Don't forget water for you and your dogs along with any snacks, sun screen, leashes, poop bags and other items you or your dog may need. Please do not leave any messes your dog makes on the path. It isn't pleasant for others who might accidentally step in it.

To get here traveling North on Loch Raven you will make a right onto Cromwell Bridge Road.From 695 you will take exit 29A and go left at the light onto Cromwell Bridge Rd

Follow Cromwell Bridge Road for about  1 mile and make a left into the park  - make sure you go to Willow Grove Farm which is the 2nd entrance long entrance into the park.

As always remember to rsvp with the number of dogs attending so we are sure to keep it to ten dogs or less for safety sake and for polite consideration of others on the trails.


Yes we cancel if there is inclement weather.

* If it is raining or other foul weather conditions I will cancel. Snow is still good hiking weather to me as long as it isn't mixed with rain or ice or comes with major wind blowing. We will cancel at least one hour prior hike time if there is inclement weather and if there are no sign ups. In hopes of giving the weather every chance of clearing for scheduled hikes I usually wait to cancel until one hour prior. Please let me know if you have a further driving distance than that and will need more notice.

please allow yourself enough time to get to the hike location, park and have you and your pups ready for hiking by the scheduled hike time. Take my number in case there is a problem. I generally arrive 15 minutes prior hike time to have my dogs ready on time.
