results.description:
A Pathfinder Society Scenario designed for 1st to 7th level characters.

When four statues of unspeakable power were found in a tomb in Osirion and then stolen, the Pathfinder Society assumed they were gone forever. When they appeared again in the illicit inventory of a Qadiran smuggler in the massive trade city of Sedeq, the Society wasted little time dispatching you there to recover them. Finding the smuggler dead and a familiar face from Absalom responsible, your task quickly becomes a race to retrieve the statues before their brutal power can be unleashed on the citizens of the Satrap. Can you find the statues in time or will Sedeq be swallowed in a plague like none Golarion has ever seen?

results.description:
Our grand finale meeting of 2015 will be lead by a familiar face to the Baltimore SharePoint community. Dan has wowed BSPUG audiences in each of our 8 years of existence and has spoken at each of our SPSBMORE events. 

You will definitely want to RSVP for this event quickly, as seats will fill up fast for his arrival. 

View Dan's Previous Session Below: 

Meet Dan Usher: 

Dan Usher is a Senior Lead Engineer (Lead Associate) at Booz Allen Hamilton where he is a lead SharePoint Solutions Manager and Architect. Over the past 10 years, he has gained an extensive amount of experience with the Microsoft Windows Networking Infrastructure and has been implementing, customizing, architecting and deploying Enterprise collaboration solutions utilizing the Microsoft SharePoint Products and Technologies, Office 365 and Azure. 

Dan is a Microsoft MVP for SharePoint Server, a former Microsoft Certified Trainer, and has attained the Microsoft Certified Solutions Expert (MCSE) for SharePoint 2013 in addition to the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate (MCSA) for Office 365. 

Dan's Specialties
Identity, Authentication and Infrastructure design

SharePoint configuration, implementation and deployment of SharePoint products and technologies 

On-premise and Cloud support and implementation.


Additional Resources

Check out Dan Usher and Scot Hoag's podcast Brewery FM below: 

Parking is free and plenty of space is available

Meeting Schedule and Agenda:

6pm      - Doors Open. Food and Networking

645pm - Announcements and Group and Industry News

655pm - Dan Usher feature presentation

815pm - Closing Remarks

About Baltimore SPUG

For 8 consecutive years, we have held a monthly meeting every third Thursday of the month. Our meeting location is ProObject located at 7467 Ridge Road, Hanover, MD.

BSPUG Delivers the Following Promise to Our Members

Each meeting is free of chargeFood and beverages will be served with Vegetarian options availableEach meeting will feature a networking sessionEach meeting will feature a SharePoint related technical discussion

Parking for our meeting location is free of charge and plenty of space is available. 

Thanks for your continued support of Baltimore SharePoint User Group throughout 2015.

Shadeed Eleazer on behalf of Team BSPUG.
results.name: Dan Usher Kicks Off BSPUG December Meetup

<a>Submit your deal now!</a> 

See real estate Sharks
feast on deals at our next

“SHARK TANK” 


MAIN EVENT  THE FEEDING FRENZY RESUMES! THIS TIME, HAVE THE SHARKS BITE ON YOUR DEAL!   We’re looking for deals to feed our hungry Sharks: the rehabbers, buy-and-hold investors, and lenders who will bring their appetites to our Main Event on December 17.

If you have a property under control and want to sell it, or you’re looking for a lender or an equity partner, 

<a>submit your deal now for consideration</a>

. Don’t have a property?  Come and learn


how the Sharks evaluate a deal!


Plus, if the Sharks don’t bite, 


you could be the one to buy the deal, perhaps funded by one of our lenders. Join us at the Sheraton Baltimore North in Towson,Thursday, December 17, 6:30 to 9:00 p.m. 


FREE admission for Baltimore REIA members.  Just $19 for guests.   

There’s blood in the water… or should we say money? We’ve gathered another school of Sharks — local real estate experts — for an encore of our popular “Shark Tank” Main Event.

If you’ve seen the popular TV show, you know what this means: people with deals and buyers with the ability to say yes — right at this event! 

About the Sharks. We’ll have rehabbers eager for their next flip… buy-and-hold investors looking to increase their rental portfolios… and lenders ready to fund deals.  These pros are ready to bite! 

About the people bringing “Shark Bait” (the deals).  We expect to have new investors getting into the game… a veteran wholesaler… even an investor-friendly realtor with potential deals from the MLS. 

Our previous “Shark Tanks” were among our most popular events ever.  Don’t miss the encore performance at our Main Event on December 17.  It’s a terrific opportunity for learning and networking! 

Like all of our Main Events, this one is FREE for Baltimore REIA members. 

Guests pay just $19.  You can pay at the door, or better still, sign up online and lock in your place. 

</a> Not a member? <a href="http://www.baltimorereia.com/join-now/">Join Baltimore REIA now, save on this event, and enjoy many other benefits.  

You’ll enjoy savings on our meetings and events all year long… vendor discounts including a 2% rebate from Home Depot… and a FREE welcome gift: $197 worth of DVDs from our own experts. 

Everyone is welcome at Baltimore REIA, and every Main Event starts with our Newbie Meet & Greet. 

New to Baltimore REIA?  New to investing?  Join us from 6:30 to 7:00 for our Newbie Meet & Greet.  Learn more about the club and feel free to ask any question about real estate investing.  We’re an association of investors, for investors.  In other words, we’re here for 

you. 

Come and get the networking and real-world education you need to build wealth.  Bring your business cards — you may find a deal right at this meeting! 

Our Main Event is 6:30 p.m. on the third Thursday of each month at the Sheraton Baltimore North, 903 Dulaney Valley Rd., Towson, MD 21286.

Click here for directions  

 You’ll enjoy our great meeting place with plenty of parking and a special discount for all of our meeting attendees.  

When you enter the garage you’ll receive a ticket.  Take it to the front desk, pay the discounted fee, and they’ll validate your ticket.

www.BaltimoreREIA.com

 Want even more education from Baltimore REIA? Check out our new Inner Circle program, with the one-on-one guidance our members have been clamoring for.

results.description:
We will be doing a HOW (Hands On Workshop) on Lightning Components. Please bring in your laptops and lets build something really awesome.

Details: Lightning and the new Lightning Experience were everywhere at Dreamforce. It's time to take the plunge!  Bring your laptop: In this hands-on workshop, you'll go beyond the theory and learn how build Lightning Components and Applications that work in the new Lightning Experience and in the Salesforce1 mobile app! You'll learn how to code the different parts of a Lightning Component, how to use events to communicate between components, how to use the brand new Lightning Design System to provide your components with a great User Experience, and how to assemble your custom components in App Builder. You'll leave with a fully functioning app you can use to jumpstart your own development.

How to Make the Most Our of this Workshop: Come prepared - you'll want to bring your laptop to this meetup.  Also, it will be beneficial, not required, but very helpful to get a head start by doing these two steps in advance:

1)  Spin up a new development org for a new environment to work out of.  Within the form, you'll specify a new username and then receive an email with a link to get logged in.  Keep track of these new creds!

2)  Configure your new org's "My Domain" by going to Setup --> My Domain.  More details here

Agenda:

• 6:30pm - Food & networking 

• 7:00pm - Workshop 

• 8:00pm - Networking, Co-Hacking, & Debugging
results.name: Hands-On Workshop: Building Lightning Components

results.description:
Our December book is A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens. Bah! Humbug! We all know the story from movies and plays but how many of us have actually read the book? Lets read a classic!

Since our discussion is held at the Nordstrom Market Cafe, I plan on enjoying dinner during our discussion. Eating or drinking is optional but I certainly plan on enjoying something to eat and drink during our discussion. The Nordstrom Market Cafe is located on the second floor of Norstroms in the Columbia Mall.

Synopsis

Ebenezer Scrooge is a miserly old man who believes that Christmas is just an excuse for people to miss work and for idle people to expect handouts. He doesn't believe in all of the good cheer and charity that the season promotes, and he makes sure everyone knows it.

That night, Scrooge is visited by the ghost of his former business associate, Jacob Marley -- a man who was as greedy and cold as Scrooge is. Marley warns Scrooge that if he continues to live so selfishly, he will spend eternity wearing the chains that his greed has built.

Three ghosts visit Scrooge successively: the Ghost of Christmas Past, the Ghost of Christmas Present, and the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come. They show Scrooge his error in valuing money over people. Scrooge is frightened by the bleak picture of his life and promises to change his ways.

First published on December 19, 1843, A Christmas Carol remains popular, having never been out of print and has been adapted many times to film, stage, opera, and other media.

Discussion Questions

1. Had you read A Christmas Carol before? Did anything surprise you in the book? I was surprised by the humor. For example, this passage near the beginning:

[Scrooge] lived in chambers which had once belonged to his deceased partner. They were a gloomy suite of rooms, in a lowering pile of building up a yard, where it had so little business to be, that one could scarcely help fancying it must have run there when it was a young house, playing at hide-and-seek with other houses, and forgotten the way out again.

2. This is a very short book, and not the only Christmas story that Dickens wrote. Why do you think that it and its message endured and became such a part of English-speaking culture?

3. Did you have a favorite part? What image or line or scene sticks with you the most, if one does?

4. How would you characterize Bob Cratchit’s attitude toward Scrooge? Scrooge’s attitude toward Cratchit? Besides literal heat, what might be the symbolism of the tiny coal fire that Cratchit has in the office?

5. Why does Scrooge say that Fred should not be happy? What does this reveal about Scrooge’s priorities?

6. What is the significance or symbolism of the fact that bells announce Marley’s ghost?

7. Why is the Ghost of Christmas Past young, small, cloaked in white and shining bright? What does he mean when he says that Scrooge made his cap and has forced him to wear it?

8. What has Marley’s ghost been doing since his death?

9. What is Scrooge’s initial attitude toward the spirit?

10. What is different about Scrooge when he says “Remember it? I could walk it with a blindfold?”

11. How does Scrooge’s relationship with his sister Fan play into the story?

12. What does the name Fezziweg suggest? When the spirit challenges Scrooge by asking if Fezziweg truly deserves such high praise for such a little party, how does Scrooge respond? How might Scrooge’s claim that Fezziweg “had the power to make us happy and to make us unhappy” reflect upon Scrooge himself?

13. How does Scrooge try to extinguish the light of the first spirit? Does he succeed? What is the light a symbol of?

14. How is what Scrooge is thinking as he lies in bed waiting to see if the spirit appears different from the previous chapter? How has Scrooge’s attitude toward his being escorted by a ghost changed?

15. How is Scrooge affected by seeing the Cratchit family?

16. What is the point of the visits with the Ghost of Christmas Present to the lighthouse and the ship?

17. Why does Fred refuse to speak against Scrooge? How does his wife differ on this matter? Fred and his wife and Bob and his wife have different views on Scrooge. What does this say about each of them?

18. What does the Ghost of Christmas Present mean when it says the boy and the girl under his robes, Ignorance and Want, are “Man’s”?

19. How does Scrooge feel about the spirit of Christmas yet to come?

20. What is the lesson Scrooge learns when the ghost shows him the Cratchit family after Tim’s death? Why is this lesson needed when Scrooge’s attitude has already changed so much?

21. Is Scrooge’s transformation believable?

results.description:
Our next meeting will start at 7pm
Meeting address:
6425 Abel St
Elkridge MD 21075
[masked]

Our meetings are always free.

Our meetings are informal and we tend to discuss whatever anyone has brought with them to show as well as discussing local rockhounding ideas.

Even though we usually plan to wrap-up around 9pm, most of us are usually still chatting at 10. It is amazing the amount of knowledge that we share with each other and the body of knowledge that we have as a group. All of our meetings have been great (even when only a few show up).

I do ask that you RSVP for our meeting, but... if you haven’t RSVP'd and would still like to come to the meeting – please do. The RSVP helps the meeting by showing others that we do have a group and that there will be a meeting that night. If you RSVP’d yes and can’t make it, that’s OK too (you can always change your RSVP at any time).

I hope that you will consider attending (newbie or old-hand). Our group has been meeting for over 3 years now. We have over 150 total members and we’ve maintained a 5 star rating for our meetings. I believe that you will enjoy yourself and we will enjoy your company too.

As always, everyone is invited to our meetings (including your non-Rockhound guests). I have videos from Cash and Treasures shows that cover some great rockhounding locations and I will bring out some of my "treasures".

I hope you can make it, we are very informal, don't forget to bring someting (rocks, fossils, yard rock, book, map, whatever) to discuss.

Wayne Homens

Founder, 
Central Maryland Rock and Mineral Exchange Meetup

http://www.meetup.com/rockhounds

Street parking is free after 6, and there are some garages close by as well.  Although we are a group, everyone will be responsible for their own bar tab. :)

See you There!

results.description:
Still have openings for two more players. Send me an email at [masked] if you're interested in joining us.

Continuing with third session of the Jade Regent Adventure Path. Here's a synopsis of the full adventure path:

In the Jade Regent Adventure Path, PCs will travel epic distances with a crew of lively NPCs, starting in the familiar nation of Varisia and ending up on the other side of the world. As a result, the primary element you should keep in mind when creating your character is the fact that while the Adventure Path begins in Sandpoint, it won’t stay there—build your character as someone eager to leave this quiet town to seek adventure elsewhere in the world and you’ll be set! This guide’s purpose is to help players create and equip their characters so they can readily take on the challenges and trials they will face along the journey to a different continent. In addition to spoiler-free details pertaining to the types of areas PCs are most likely to encounter on their legendary voyage, this guide will provide campaign traits to f lesh out characters’ backgrounds, advice on races and classes, and rules regarding their relationships with important NPCs and the caravan they’ll be traveling with.
results.name: Jade Regent Campaign Cont'd (Starting a bit earlier tonight)

results.description:
Please join us for this virtual kickoff for the 21-Day Vegan Kickstart Challenge that will officially kick off on January 1st, 2016.


We're all going to register ahead of time, on December 18th, for this virtual "Meetup" (i.e. - registering online for the Kickstart Challenge).  We're calling this online registration a virtual Meetup event, which is preceded by, and followed by in-person and/or conference call Meetups.   (You can register before or after, but we recommend Dec 18th) 

It's important to register well before January 1st to have at least a few weeks to gather some ingredients, and review and practice cooking some new recipes before the program starts on January 1st. 


You can use the page below to view and print the shopping list for the program's provided recipes, learn about vegan convenience foods, get the smartphone  app, and more! You can review the suggested menus for all 3 weeks of the program as well:

http://www.pcrm.org/kickstartHome/mealplan/week-1


Anytime (starting now), through this Meetup website, please ask questions, get to know other participants, find buddies, and ask for a coach.  There are people experienced with plant-based diets here, including this Meetup's organizers, who want to be your coach.  You can have more than one coach if you like.  Coaches would typically talk with you by phone perhaps once a week or as needed, may be able to go shopping with you if needed, etc.  (We also encourage you to join the twice monthly conference calls already scheduled on this Meetup page on the third Thursdays, and Fourth Tuesdays of each month). 


The 21 Day Vegan Kickstart Challenge, sponsored by PCRM: The Physician's Committee for Responsible Medicine, is FREE, to everyone and can be followed by anyone with access to the internet.

To register, follow the link below and click on desired language, then answer a few questions, and you are all set!

http://www.pcrm.org/health/diets/kickstart/kickstart-programs


You may already know that a whole-food plant-based diet can prevent and in some cases reversing diseases such as diabetes, heart disease, hypertension, and cancers, such as breast, colon, pancreatic, prostate, and others.

Based on research by Neal Barnard, M.D., one of America’s leading health advocates, this program is designed for anyone wanting to explore the health benefits of a plant-based diet.

Here are the local events that this Meetup group (Baltimore Nutrition As Medicine) has scheduled to support you through PCRM's online Kickstart program: 

December 18th - December 31st - Virtual sign up and preparation for the program

Tuesday December 22nd - Optional Conference call with a Medical Doctor,  Registered Dietitian and other participants

(Plus any additional calls or meetings you arrange with your local coaches / buddies)

January 1st - Virtual kick off - when you start eating healthy vegan food 100% - for just three weeks!

Friday January 8th -  Our regular monthly in-person potluck/ support Meetup at the usual time and place. 

Thursday January 14th  - 6:30 pm -   Our regularly scheduled conference call with a Medical Doctor, Registered Dietitian, and other participants.

Saturday January 23th - Celebration in the banquet room at Mr. Chan's restaurant in Pikesville, with an incredibly delicious vegan menu. (Participants order and pay for their own meals). 

(Participate in as many or as few of these events as you like - they're all optional).

Once you sign-up you will receive a daily email from PCRM with recipes, tips, cooking demonstrations, inspiration and encouragement. 

There's something about going 100% vegan for 3 weeks that transforms your preferences and taste buds.   It takes 3 weeks to start seeing results and to begin to really taste and enjoy new foods.   

So you should have everything necessary to complete to the program, including support form the Baltimore Nutrition as Medicine team, from other participants, as well as a vegan coach, if you would like one. 

This is a great program that can set you on the path of healthy living, preventing, improving or reversing many common health problems, while introducing you to the vast variety of tasty plant based foods that will leave your taste buds satisfied! 

The Baltimore Nutrition As Medicine team:  Joe, Vlad, Emily & Jamila
results.name: Sign up and preparation for the 21 Day Vegan kickstart

group.name: Baltimore Nutrition As Medicine Education & Support Group

results.description:
GRATITUDE AND GIVING THANKS

Discussion about the way of thinking and  life that will lead to the most peaceful and greatest attitude of all, gratitude.  

This will be a reflective and fruitful way to embrace Life, close the year and prepare for a new one with a clear mind.

Friday, December 18, 2015

6:30 PM

2500 Brighton Dam Road, Brookville, MD (map)[masked] [masked]

Treasures of The Heart

"HEART" is a treasure chest.   By consciously living in and from the Heart and experiencing it's energy, we will uncover the treasures of humanity.

Mehrdad Mizani, who is a self realized teacher who has been interviewed by Rick Archer on "Buddha at the Gas Pump" and has recently published a book "How are You Treating Life?" (Go to www.catalystpublishing.org for details) will lead this discussion:

Love offering for The Way of Heart will be appreciated.

6:30 to 7:45 .... Potluck dinner

8:00 to 8:05 .... Short guided meditation.

8:05 to 10:00 .... Talk and discussion.

10:00 to 11:00 .... Music and singing as well as socializing.

Free parking in the two lower parking lots.

Feel free to bring house slippers.  Blankets will be provided for your comfort.

“No matter how much someone wishes to love others, it’s simply not possible without growing the heart.When we understand that only a mature heart can be the source of true and constant love, we realize that it is imperative for us to learn how the heart is meant to grow. No matter what else we do, the primary focus of life – thoughts, words and actions- should be on the growth of the heart in all its different realms.As we grow in the realms of the heart, we become able to see, feel and understand people around us. Therefore, our relationships with others become deeper and more harmonious. As the heart grows, so does the love, and so does our ability to experience lasting happiness in all areas of our lives.” Mehrdad Mizani

There will be an organized opportunity at this event for Spiritual Singles to come together as a group to introduce ourselves to each other. 

To see a sample of Mehrdad's talk, go to the following links:http://batgap.com/mehrdad-mizani/
http://www.youtube.com/user/thewayofheart

Below Mehrdad on Jordan Rich show....delightful

http://boston.cbslocal.com/?podcast_url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.podtrac.com%2Fpts%2Fredirect.mp3%2Fnyc.podcast.play.it%2Fmedia%2Fd0%2Fd0%2Fd1%2Fd2%2FdI%2FdJ%2FdO%2F12IJO_4.MP3%3Fauthtok%3D5562056298000598828_6ScUksjm73lKMqzU4LwR363IfI&podcast_name=Music+For+The+Soul&podcast_artist=Jordan+Rich&station_id=91&tag=&dcid=CBS.BOSTON
results.how_to_find_us: GPS/Mapquest
results.name: GRATITUDE-A Key To Peace -Embrace Life Now- Chat With Mehrdad

results.description:
Join Baltimore's Pagans, witches, and elders as we celebrate Yule with an evening of food, drink, ritual, drama, stories, music, games, and spontaneous Pagan fun!

Please Note: This month's meetup will take place on the THIRD FRIDAY of the month to avoid conflicts with other holiday celebrations.

THIS MONTH'S THEME:

~ YULE CELEBRATION! ~

ATTIRE FOR THE EVENING:
Whatever your heart desires.  Yule finery is encouraged!

HOW TO FIND OUR GROUP:
We will be upstairs in our favorite private room above the front of the establishment. Meet-up signs will be posted.


COST OF ADMISSION:
No coin of the realm required, other than paying for any food and drink you order, plus tax and tip.

DINNER AND DRINKS:
Order from a wide variety of scrumptious delights. Check out the extensive menu.</a>


ENTERTAINMENT:
Yule merriment!

WANT TO HELP?:
If you would like to help plan, decorate, perform, or lead some of the activities for this event, contact Isis.  The more, the merrier!

SCHEDULE:

7:00 pm

Dinner, Drink, Music & Socializing

After Dinner

(Starting between 8:30 pm and 9:00 pm)

Yule Ritual

Battle of the Holly King & the Oak King

Stories & Drama

Yule Music

Traditional Yule Fun & Games


After Presentation

(Starting between 10:30 pm and 11:00 pm, and continuing until 2:00 am)

Conversation and Spontaneous Pagan Fun - Stay if you can, leave if you must!


DRIVING DIRECTIONS:

For turn-by-turn directions from your starting location, go to


Map Quest
<a href="http://www.mapquest.com">http://www.mapquest.c...

or Google Maps.
http://maps.google.co...

PARKING:
Lots of street parking is available right outside the pub.

BRING:
Yourself, your sense of humor, $ to pay your tab, and a designated driver.

See you there!

results.description: Our monthly service is Friday evening, December 18. Help us once again welcome the sabbath with a lively, friendly, and sincere service led by Rabbi Jonathan Panitz, followed by oneg and kibbitzing. We also often have several musicians help out, especially Aaron and his guitar, with tunes from multiple Jewish traditions. Our service is structured yet informal, mixing Hebrew and English, and usually having an interactive and provocative discussion. Join us - everyone is welcome. No RSVP is required, but if you do RSVP, you'll receive reminders.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter from Falls Road at the gate, turn hard right, then left at the second street, Hamlet Hill Road, and proceed up the hill. The clubhouse and pool are at the end on the left, with parking.

results.description:
This night the salsa night will be held at Mex as Havana Club is hosting a private event. All other details are the same.

Havana Club is a nightclub for fun loving adults and is home to Salsa every Friday night in Baltimore city. Baltimore's hottest upscale club gets even better as salsa takes over one of the coolest midtown hotspots. Fun for the discriminating taste, a classy and sexy Latin dance party hosted by SalsaNow. Come experience the excitement of the inner city nightlife and what dancing at this trendy hotspot is really like to get your weekend started right.

Havana Club in Baltimore has brought Salsa Fridays back after many years. Come out to what once again is the best dance spot in town and be a part of THE hottest salsa night in town. Every Friday join us for an upscale salsa club experience and dance to the greatest hits of Salsa, Mambo, Merengue, Cha cha cha and Bachata with some popular tunes thrown into the mix after midnight to make for a terrific night of dancing and fun.

Baltimore's best upscale nightclub got even better since Salsa Fridays with SalsaNow made Havana Club their home. More than doubling the dance floor space and a rotation of the best salsa DJs on the East Coast. This week DJ Stephen Greene provides the music to make your body and soul dance all night. Lets get this party started!

* Salsa Lessons 8:30 - 10 PM: Salsa On1 Basic 8:30 PM, Salsa Partnering Combination 9:15 PM, $10 or FREE with a paid dinner entree.
* FREE Admission until 10 PM, $10 after
* Valet Parking $10, front door service and garaged parking for the evening.

DRESS CODE: Strictly adhered to. Dress to Impress. No sportswear of any kind, No rips, No T-Shirts or shorts, No caps or hats, No sneakers, work boots or flip flops. Only dress jeans are allowed.
results.name: Salsa night including lessons at Mex (Power Plant Live)

Club meetings include a brief business meeting, after which the group gathers informally over light refreshments to talk about just about anything including (on occasion) science fiction literature and media.

Meetings are held in members’ homes in Virginia and Maryland.

The Maryland location is in a multi-pet friendly home. 10 minute bus ride from the Greenbelt Metro Station. There is one flight of stairs to enter the home. Meeting is up/down a half flight of stairs.

The Virginia location is slightly over a mile from the Ballston Metro station, there is also a bus. There is one flight of stairs to enter the home.

Both locations have ample street parking.

results.description: According to folklore, The Red Star gained its name and reputation from sailors visiting Fell's Point. They docked, lonely and water-logged, hoping to find some of the comforts of home. The sailors knew Fell's Point was a good place to find a warm meal and a cold ale, along with more "intimate" necessities. The blue laws of the time prohibited the customary red lights in the district... so resourceful women painted nautical red stars on the sidewalks leading the sailors to their doors. To the lonely men's delight, The Red Star was born.

results.description:
I don't want to call this a beginner ride as we will be in patapsco, and there will always be things / obstacles here, but if you are a strong beginner who knows how to shift, can handle 10 miles, and is comfortable on roots, and around 1,000 feet of elevation / climbing, and can handle a small log or two, you will be able to handle this ride.  The second ride will be tougher, harder, and longer!  Mileage on this one will be dictated by group and time.

Disclaimer: Mountain biking is a risky sport, By signing up for this meetup you are agreeing you have seen, read, and understand our waiver located here:http://www.meetup.com/MVD-Mountain-Bikers/pages/Standard_Waiver_for_Meetup_Rides/


Where/Directions: Rockburn Elementary.  Google the address above.  We will be in the school parking lot.

What time: Meet between 8:45 and 9:00 AM at parking lot. Wheels rolling by 9:00.  You will notice a second ride, so we have to be wheels rolling by 9 for those of us to stand a chance to get back on time for the second ride.

Pace: Pace will be casual, approx. 6 to 7 mph moving average.  Attitude is laid-back and friendly. This is a no-drop ride, i.e., we wait up for everyone at intersections. (Note: if you don’t want to wait up for slower riders, this is NOT the ride for you. It is NOT a training ride, and Racer X will be disappointed).

Terrain: Ranges from Easy to Intermediate. Most trails are in great shape, but some sections may be loose and/or soft, i.e., plan on some mud spots. There are a few steep/long climbs, technical sections, and a stream crossing or two. There are also active road sections. This is a friendly ride, so we will wait up for everyone, just be advised that the terrain can be somewhat difficult in places. This video of Patapsco represents most of the area we will hit:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i0aXny9lKbg

Distance: Approx. 11 miles. Exact route may change depending on group dynamics, trail conditions, etc., but we will be on single track most of the day.  I will shorten the route if needed to get back on time for the next ride.  This is the anticipated route. https://www.strava.com/routes/3662601


Duration: Ride time: approx. 1 hour 45 minutes if we average 6 mph the entire ride; total time: approx. 2 hours due to this being a no drop group ride, and for the fact we need to be back for the 2nd ride.  Note: wheels roll at stated time, so please don’t be late. 


Bring: Helmet (required), water (as much as you can carry), spare tube/patch kit, pump/CO2, multi-tool, I.D., emergency contact info where it can be easily located on your person, food (fuel)and a good attitude, as this ride is as much about camaraderie as it is about riding. Take a look at your bike and make sure it is in good working condition (Ptap will take its toll on the bike). 

Weather: Shine Only (there will undoubtedly be some mud, but no ride if it’s raining or the trails are too muddy). Protect our trails and don’t ride them when they’re fragile.

Ride Organizer(s): Craig

Craig P, 44three-eight4five-three6eight9

results.description:
https://img.evbuc.com/https%3A%2F%2Fimg.evbuc.com%2Fhttp%253A%252F%252Fcdn.evbuc.com%252Fimages%252F14324359%252F132604760860%252F1%252Foriginal.jpg%3Frect%3D7%252C156%252C344%252C172%26s%3D09dff39ac175c10b3eaefb7f6ac8b0de?w=600&s=88da8316da0e15074efec285d0c409ed

Rummage up the Ugliest Sweater you can find and celebrate the Holidays by participating in the Merriest 5K of the year. Join thousands of runners, walkers and prancers from around the nation as The Ugly Sweater Run tours North America. If you’ve never participated in a 5K, this is a perfect way to burn some calories, have some fun and immediately replace those calories with a warm hot chocolate and a Samuel Adams beverage. All you have to do is register!

The run is approximately 3.1 miles, through city streets and scenic parks. The start line includes massive inflatables, photo stations, games and the most cheerful holiday music. Once on course, you’ll find holiday themed stations at every mile. Ditch the traditional water or Gatorade as good ol’ fashioned hot chocolate will be stationed on course as refreshment.

Once you’ve completed the merriest run of your life, join us for some post-event festivities. We have everything your five-year old self could want with a few perks of adulthood. Take a much-deserved break from the shopping frenzy, and celebrate your sweater filled day with a Samuel Adams beverage and other holiday goodies. Awards for Best Ugly Sweater, Best Kids Sweater, Best Pet Attire and Best Real/Fake Mustache/Beard will be handed out. Register now and join us for a truly unforgettable tradition!

Rules

We suggest arriving in the ugliest of ugly sweater you can find, hand in hand with your best friends. Other than that, no official rules apply, its a free for all of fun!

Must bring ID to receive adult beverage. That’s a given.

Pricing

$25 Early Registration
$30 starting Jul. 28, 2015
$35 starting Aug. 24, 2015
$40 starting Sep. 21, 2015
$50 day of registration, if available. (So sign up early!)

What do I get :

Does it get any better than this? Why yes, it does! Each Ugly Sweater participant receives a custom collectable knit hat, unlimited hot chocolate, and a Samuel Adams beverage (if you’re of age of course!). All included with your entry to what my grandmother has dubbed “The best and only reason I would let you take my christmas sweater from the basement.”


Packet Pick up:

Date: Dec. 18, 2015

Time: 11:00am – 7:00pm

Location: Sports Authority | 8200 Perry Hall Blvd., Nottingham, MD 21236

Event Day Packet Pick-Up: 7:00am-9:00am
*There will be a limited amount of packets on race day, so please arrive early. We encourage all participants to pick up their packets the day before the race.

More info here :  http://theuglysweaterrun.com/locations/baltimore-maryland/
results.name: Race 09 of 50 : The Ugly Sweater Run- Baltimore

results.description:
The Maryland Book Bank has provides new and gently used children's books to disadvantaged families in Baltimore. Their goal is to spark family reading at home by making sure there are plenty of books available.

Volunteers are needed to help organize books at the Book Bank. On days when the weather is favorable, volunteer organizers at the Book Bank often arrange for volunteers to work outdoors!

This event has been very popular with volunteers who work with children. An extra benefit of sorting books for the Maryland Book Bank is the nostalgia trip you'll experience when you see books that you just might remember from your childhood...!

For those who are interested, we may go to lunch at a nearby restaurant after this event.

How to find the warehouse:

The Book Bank is located at the rear entrance of The Baltimore Sun warehouse complex, where parking is available for all volunteers.

The Book Bank can be difficult to find, so be sure to follow the directions at

http://marylandbookbank.org/directions.html

The rear entrance on Guilford Road is a locked gate. In order to gain entrance, you will need to use the intercom on the left side of the gate and tell the guard that you're a volunteer for Maryland Book Bank.  In case the guard is not at the desk, we'll post a phone number for the Book Bank staff, who will come out to open the gate.

One of our volunteers has made a short YouTube video (about 1 minute in length) that might help you find the warehouse.  The video starts at the intersection of  N. Calvert St. and E. Centre St., goes through the back entrance gate on Guilford Ave, and ends at the door of the Book Bank warehouse.   This video can be found at http://youtu.be/I5cwEo_aKfQ .
results.name: Maryland Book Bank

results.description:
HIKE DESCRIPTION,

This will be a very long but very rewarding hike for those who are fit enough to hike for 5 hours with a 15 minuet break to snack and stretch. You will need 64oz of water and a substantial snack to complete this hike comfortably. Please understand this hike is NOT for everybody and if you are not confident in your ability to complete this hike in a 3 mile a hour average over the entire 14 miles than you should not sign up for this hike. We will burn approximately 3,000 calories on this hike so a good breakfast is a must.

We will not hike in the rain but you must dress appropriately for the weather conditions. I will update this as the date gets closer and the weather conditions are known. I hope to see you on the trail!

If you don't have a profile picture you will not be allowed to attend this hike.


There is a river crossing on this hike that will dependent on the river flow. If there is a recent heavy rain we won't be able to cross into McKeldin and I will reroute the hike to get the full 14 miles in.


We can go out for a late lunch/early dinner afterwards if there is enough interest.

http://dnr2.maryland.gov/publiclands/Documents/Patapsco_mckeldinmap.pdf

Update... The weather looks great for the hike. It will be 32  degrees at the start of the hike and 42 degrees at the finish. Breezy winds of 15 mph and  sunny skies. If you normally hike with poles or walking sticks you should bring them. Dress comfortably in thin layers that you can take off or unzip as you warm up and wear good hiking shoes/boots.Gloves are good idea as well. If you are coming from far away and want to use a bathroom or get last minuet food/water there is a Weis grocery store right off of route 70- 2 miles away at 10825 Birmingham Way, Woodstock, MD 21163.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in the parking area accross from the Woodstock inn.
results.name: 14 mile fitness hike @ Patapsco State Park! Woodstock to McKeldin.

results.description:
This ride is going to be awesome! Rocks, jumps, drops, log overs, killer ups, but awesome downs to. If you got the legs you will have a ton of fun!  24ish miles, 3200 feet of elevations....If the trail has log, jump, drop, or rock garden this ride will hit it. Be prepared!

Disclaimer: Mountain biking is a risky sport, By signing up for this meetup you are agreeing you have seen, read, and understand our waiver located here:http://www.meetup.com/MVD-Mountain-Bikers/pages/Standard_Waiver_for_Meetup_Rides/


This ride is strictly intermediate terrain including log overs, rocks, stream crossings, very steep climbs and in general pretty technical. It's not the water shed, but it is demanding. Please understand this is an intermediate ride due to this terrain, and distance.

Where/Directions: Rockburn Elementary School.  Meet in the schools parking lot.

What time: Meet between 10:45 and 11:00 AM at parking lot. Wheels rolling by 11:00am.  I am also leading the easier ride at 9am.  We should be back by 11:00 am.  If we are not you may be waiting on us a few minutes, but we will be there.

Pace: Pace will be approx. 7-9 mph moving average (some of the climbs I'll be as slow as 3 mph, just a warning). Please note people tend to lose about 1 mph average in Patapsco as compared to Rosaryville, or Fairland. These paces are appropriate for most average riders who have good cardio endurance, but not for beginners, due to terrain and mileage. Attitude is laid-back and friendly. This is a no-drop ride, i.e., we wait up for everyone at intersections, but as it is a long ride, we will only wait as long as the last person needs to catch a breath. 

Terrain: Ranges from Easy to Difficult. Most trails are in great shape, but some sections may be loose and/or soft, i.e., plan on some mud spots. There are a few steep/long climbs, rocks and technical sections, and a stream crossing or two. A couple of sections may be a hike-a-bike for some. There are also active road sections. This is a friendly ride, so we will wait up for everyone, just be advised that the terrain can be somewhat difficult in places. This video of Patapsco represents most of the area we will hit:0

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i0aXny9lKbg

Distance: Approx. 24 miles, give or take a few (you are looking at 34 if you do the earlier easier ride). Exact route may change depending on group dynamics, trail conditions, etc., but we will be on single track most of the day. Only about 2 miles of this route is paved (grist mill trail, and river road). Please understand this will be demanding. Please also note we will be climbing about 3,200 feet (close to 4,500 if you both rides) in elevation. This is the anticipated route of this last 24 miles.  If you show up for both rides, make sure you look at the other loop also, posted under the other ride.  https://www.strava.com/routes/3662605

Duration: Ride time: approx. 3 hours 45 minutes if we average 7 mph the entire ride; total time: approx. 4 to 4.5 hours due to this being a no drop group ride. The slower pace group may be as long as 5 hours. Total time will really depend on group dynamics, trail conditions, wait-ups, mechanicals and/or number of stops. As mentioned, no-drop, which may add to total time.  We will also take at least one 15 minute break to refuel.


Bring: Helmet (required), water (as much as you can carry, but we will have a chance to refill at around 10 miles, 14 miles, and 20 miles), spare tube/patch kit, pump/CO2, multi-tool, I.D., emergency contact info where it can be easily located on your person, food (fuel)and a good attitude, as this ride is as much about camaraderie as it is about riding. Take a look at your bike and make sure it is in good working condition (Ptap will take its toll on the bike). Every 10 miles or so we will be back at the park where we can refill water if need be.

Weather: Shine Only (there will undoubtedly be some mud, but no ride if it’s raining or the trails are too muddy). Protect our trails and don’t ride them when they’re fragile.

Ride Organizer(s): Craig

Craig P, 4four3-eight4five-3six8nine

results.description:
The twenty-first century is when everything changes. And you've got to be ready.

 

 

The Doctor Is In!  If you think "Fezzes are cool!" then this is the Discussion Meetup for you!

What? What? What?:

Dr. Who Discussion Meetup!

Where in the Whoniverse:

“Somewhere there’s danger, somewhere there’s injustice, somewhere else, the tea’s getting cold.”  and that place is Amazing Spiral: Books, Comics, Toys & More!

When:  January 24th from  12pm - 2pm  (come for whatever part you can, often people come at 12 or at 1 and leave and stay as their schedule allows).[Note: This is a time change from 2014, when we met from 1 -3pm]  Then every third Saturday from 12 to 2pm for 2015.  Please call Amazing Spiral if there is inclement weather to see if the group is meeting or not. Amazing Spiral[masked]

Topics: January - The Christmas Episode is on the agenda.  What is the regular agenda? Er..."I will explain later..."  But we are getting a projector that can be hooked up to a computer, so viewing "Stuff" will be on it!

Who: The Doctor is In!   Dr. Anthony Spencer, Heather Schneider and Driana Pearlman have all stepped into the Tardis to lead our erstwhile group.  We know this because we built the Tardis as part of Dr. Who Day on July 26th, 2014.  Having the Power of Three means that we will never have to cancel the group for lack of moderator!!!!!

Why:

"The twenty-first century is when everything changes. And you've got to be ready."

and because we all need a little (or a lot) more Who in our lives!

How:

In costume is welcome!

Don't worry if you have only seen a few episodes, even if those episodes were decades ago!  As long as you have an interest in Talking Who Talk then you are ready!

Please check out Doctor Who Anonymous on Meet up for more cool Who-Peeps!

 

Look for Spider-Man to find Amazing Spiral: Books, Comics, Toys, GAMES & More!

We are across from the Senator Theater and around the corner from Belvedere Square Market Shops.

Ample parking in the back and on the street.

results.description:
“[A] luminous, Marquez-esque tale.” —O, The Oprah Magazine

From the New York Times bestselling author of The Dovekeepers andThe Museum of Extraordinary Things: a forbidden love story set on the tropical island of St. Thomas about the extraordinary woman who gave birth to painter Camille Pissarro—the Father of Impressionism.

Growing up on idyllic St. Thomas in the early 1800s, Rachel dreams of life in faraway Paris. Rachel’s mother, a pillar of their small refugee community of Jews who escaped the Inquisition, has never forgiven her daughter for being a difficult girl who refuses to live by the rules. Growing up, Rachel’s salvation is their maid Adelle’s belief in her strengths, and her deep, life-long friendship with Jestine, Adelle’s daughter. But Rachel’s life is not her own. She is married off to a widower with three children to save her father’s business. When her husband dies suddenly and his handsome, much younger nephew, Frédérick, arrives from France to settle the estate, Rachel seizes her own life story, beginning a defiant, passionate love affair that sparks a scandal that affects all of her family, including her favorite son, who will become one of the greatest artists of France.

Building on the triumphs of The Dovekeepers and The Museum of Extraordinary Things, set in a world of almost unimaginable beauty, The Marriage of Opposites showcases the beloved, bestselling Alice Hoffman at the height of her considerable powers. Once forgotten to history, the marriage of Rachel and Frédérick is a story that is as unforgettable as it is remarkable.
results.name: Let's meetup and discuss The Marriage of Opposites by Alice Hoffman

results.description:
Come and celebrate! Suzanne has graciously offered to host our last group event of the year!

Between all the shopping, baking, parties, wrapping, decorating, and travel, most of us would put “more time” as the number one item on our holiday wish lists. So this year, why not kill two turtledoves with one stone by having a cookie and candy swap party? You are invited for a fun fête which will leave you with enough treats to supply the rest of your holiday festivities (and even some gifting). Don't worry about being a chef, just make them with love and your favorite holiday colors. Plus Saturday morning baking and decorating is therapeutic! Here's the deal:

1. Bring a couple dozen (double the number you want to take home) of your favorite holiday cookies or candy, a platter to display them on, and a dozen 3x5 recipe cards to share
--Cookies/candy should be homemade (by an adult) and not burnt
--Cookies/candy should be seasonally appropriate
--Cookies/candy should be imperishable enough to last several days after baking
--Cookies/candy must be stackable

2. We will provide the following:
--Coffee and Tea for the goodie sampling
--Some savory finger food and adult beverages to offset the sweetness of the sweets (which I'm sure we will be sampling as well as collecting!)

Have fun and see you there!
results.name: Holiday Party: Cookie and Candy Swap

results.description:
Gaelle has been dancing since she could walk, she began studying ballet, Jazz, and tap at the conservatory of Longjumeau which is located in France. At the age of 18, Gaelle was among the few to be selected as part of a dance group called “TILENZ’S”. As part of "TILENZ'S" she was able to perform dance routines for artists and events across France and all throughout Europe. Her passion for music and dance allowed her to excel in the dance world. 
An extraordinary dancer, Gaelle has performed and choreographed songs with Koffi Olomide, Papa Wemba, Elizio, Samy Diko, Dr Sakis, Noyau Dur, Jessy El Matador, La Selesao, Stella Mouna, Marquis (band group), Janelia, Bebey Bass, Becky Umeh, and other Afro-Caribbean superstars to name a few. She was given the title of "Queen of Dancehall" in Paris on 2006. She also has won dance battles in Paris such as Hip-Hop music Howard (Dancehall category).


Gaelle moved to the United States from Paris to pursue her education in 2009 and her career in dance. She is originally is from the Caribbean Island of  “Martinique where the lively spirit of the people can be found through dance.

Gaelle has been teaching dance in the United States since 2011 in diverse dance studios such as Rumbero, Princess Moon, and Dance at Dupont Circle, dance studios and has recently obtained a Zumba License (2014) to expand on her love for chorography and dance.

She will introduce dance forms from Democratic Republic of Congo, Cote d'Ivoire, Jamaica and the West Indies.

Students will learn the basic technique and movement for N'dombolo, Soukous, Coupé décalé, Mapouka, Zouk and Ragga/Dancehall. Also will gain confidence to perform dances in social settings, clubs, street dances and on stage while increasing physical fitness. RSVP for your  dance class and look at our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/groups/AfroCaribbeanDance/?fref=ts

results.description:
From the #1 Essence bestselling and award-winning author Victoria Christopher Murray comes Stand Your Ground, a new novel about two women who are faced with the same tragedy.


A black teenage boy is dead. A white man shot him. Was he standing his ground or was it murder?

Janice Johnson is living every black mother’s nightmare. Her seventeen-year-old son was murdered and the shooter has not been arrested. Can the D.A. and the police be trusted to investigate and do the right thing? Should Janice take advantage of the public outcry and join her husband alongside the angry protestors who are out for revenge?

Meredith Spencer is married to the man accused of the killing and she sees her husband and the situation with far more clarity than anyone realizes. What she knows could blow the case wide open, but what will that mean for her life and that of her son? Will she have the courage to come forward in time so that justice can be done?

Stand Your Ground is a pulse-pounding meditation on race, motherhood, marriage, and vigilante justice that will have readers spellbound until its shocking end.

**UGLY SWEATER CONTEST**

Come dressed in your ugliest holiday sweater or outfit. We will have a private vote for the winner. I wish I could win but, I will participate.  :)

**SECRET SANTA GIFT EXCHANGE**

We are having another gift exchange but doing it a little different this year. Check out the rules below:

1. Each guest must bring a wrapped gift. (Value: $20.00)

2. Each guest will add their gift to the gift stack and select a private number for the gift exchange order.

3. The first person has the honor to select their wrapped gift and unwrap it.

4. The second person has the honor to select their wrapped gift to keep or choose to exchange it with the first person. However, this decision must be made prior to unwrapping their gift. If the gift is kept, it must be unwrapped. If the gift is exchanged, it must be unwrapped by the new owner.

5. The third person has the honor to select their wrapped gift to keep or choose to exchange it for any unwrapped gift. However, this decision must be made prior to unwrapping their gift. If the gift is kept, it must be unwrapped. If the gift is exchanged, it must be unwrapped by the new owner.

6. Once a gift has been received three (3) times, it can no longer be exchanged and will remain with its third owner.

7. This will continue until all gifts are exchanged.

results.description:
Bethany's Story is a documentary about the healing power of food. Bethany lived the life of a normal teenage girl before she became paralyzed by a bad reaction to medication and was told she would never walk again.


The documentary covers her amazing recovery as she makes dramatic lifestyle changes. Featuring interviews with leading nutrition experts and medical doctors, Bethany's Story is a testament to the power of food as medicine, as well as the courage of a young girl to face an immense obstacle, overcome it and in the process help inspire all of us to make forward progress in our lives, whatever our challenge may be.
results.name: Free Movie: Bethany's Story: The Power from Within

results.description:
“Once the Blue Flame of our Father God’s Power and the Pink Flame of our Mother God’s Love were perfectly balanced in the Divinity of our Heart, they merged into a magnificent Violet Flame. This Sacred Fire is known as the Violet Flame of God’s Infinite Perfection.

We will invoke the frequencies of the 5th-Dimensional Crystalline Solar Violet Flame that Cosmic Law will allow to transform, transmute and dissolve fear based conditioning on a cellular level.”

Join us for a group Violet Flame meditation, an evening of Wisdom sharing, Sound Alchemy with crystal singing bowls.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Violet Flame is a unique spiritual energy that can help you in all areas of your life. It can heal emotional and physical problems, improve relationships and finances, help you grow spiritually, or just make life easier. It is the most advanced spiritual tool given to mankind to cleanse our karma without having to face or problems directly. As my mentor and teacher Liz Draman used to say "clear the trauma without the drama". It will literally clear the negativity around a specific situation, illness, etc. when invoked. It transmutes our karmic records into pure light. It has the power to transmute, to change and raise energy that has slow vibration into energy of higher vibration.

Decrees have a mystical power to them. They invoke the power and spirit of your innate divinity, the power of God that resides within you. Decrees are spoken out loud and release the power of the Word through the throat chakra. Every time you speak a decree out loud, you are drawing upon spirit so that God can act in your life in an expedient way.

Benefits of the Violet Flame: Transform fear into courage, Transform anxiety into peace, Heal personal and planetary karma, Clears karma at a cellular level, Raises energy body to a higher vibration, Spiritual accelleration, Improves relationships, Quickens the mind, Accelerates personal growth, Purifies negative energy, Transforms families and communities, Rejuvinates the physical body, Transforms illness, and more......

If there is a situation in your life that you would like to heal quickly, then this is to tool for you!

results.description:
The Short Film Festival Night at BSFS is back! Thanks muchly to actor, director and BSFS member Paul Sulsky for taking over the reins and getting this event going again!

Every 3rd Saturday of the month at 7:00PM at the BSFS building, we screen candidates for the next Balticon Short Film Festival, highlights from web series, previews of current/upcoming indie films, and review highlights from previous Balticon Short Film Festivals.


This month we have a quirky film featuring zombies and a sorority house, some innovative animated shorts and some very well-produced European shorts, plus a couple of terrific music videos.


Admission is free. Come out and join us!

*FYI for those new to BSFS events*: The Baltimore Science Fiction Society owns its own building at 3310 East Baltimore Street. When an event is scheduled at BSFS HQ, the building is open to everyone, whether you are a BSFS member or not. Both new people and regulars are encouraged to come to events.
results.how_to_find_us: The 40, 22 and 23 MTA buses run to the corner of Baltimore and Highland Avenue. And Parking is available on the street.

results.description:
We are having a Yule ritual with an open circle on Saturday evening, and having a proper overnight vigil with fun, food, and games ending with a dawn rite on Sunday morning.  You are free to join us only for the Saturday evening ritual, come after the ritual and stay for the party, or stay for the vigil and join us for the dawn rite!

This can be a very deep rite, even though lots of silliness ensues during the night. For those who stay the night, you stand vigil on the longest night to ensure the birth of a new year. This rite goes back millennia, and staying up can put you into a bit of a trance state and connect you with some incredible ancestral energy. Most cultures had rites or vigils for the birth of a new year, and you are tapping in to that -- all while playing games and snacking!

Plans are evolving quickly, but here is the tentative schedule:

What to Bring

Please bring a potluck dish, ideally something with some thought or care, and your warm smile.

If you have a god or goddess or item you wish to celebrate and include for the altar, please bring that.

The ritual is kid friendly, but we ask that children be attended to or at least well behaved.  For those staying overnight, something comfy to sleep in if you wish to sleep, a pair of pajamas or comfortable clothing, and something warm to wear in case you wish to attend the outdoor Yule fire. Please read about the Oath Log part of the ritual, so you can think about things in advance! Finally, we could use a few things for the vigil like a coffee maker or two. If you wish to offer games, feel free to bring one!

The vigil closes at dawn. Weather depending, we will all go outside to welcome the new day. Please make sure you have some clothes to handle that... even it if it just a comfy blanket!

Arrive before 8:15 PM, or come after 9 PM.

Yule Rite Prep 8:00 PM

We will go over the ritual, which will be about 30 - 40 minutes in length, and collect our thoughts so our energies will be united in ritual.

Yule Rite 8:15 PM (but possibly as late as 8:30 PM)

Ritual is designed to be a complete ritual for those who are not staying for the vigil, and an opening for the vigil to those who plan on staying until the closing rite.

Intention is to celebrate Yule, open a space for the vigil, as well as prepare the space for fun and merriment.

We will have an Oath Log.  People may step forward in the ritual and boast about their accomplishments this past year, and make intentions for what they will accomplish this next year. This is a great time to ask for divine guidance and intervention to help manifest your desires. Please remember that this rite has Norse origins, so make intentions that you actively intend to pursue.  While it is recommended that your intentions be spoken aloud, you are welcome to state them silently if privacy is needed.

You are welcome to wear ritual robes, but your stylish pajamas or festive clothes are encouraged!

Yule Party 9:00 PM

If you arrive late, please wait until the ritual closes and join us here.  You are welcome to stay until the closing rite in the morning even if you were not present.  We will have some yummy food and drinks, but are counting on your thoughtful contributions to really make this memorable!

Candles will be lit throughout the night to measure the hours until dawn by those that are staying for the vigil.

In modern times, my experience is that some people are crashed out in a puppy pile or in their sleeping bags in rooms at 2 AM, others talk or scry in the fires, and a group of people play roleplaying or board games.  I have a ton of Euro games, and if people want I can run a D&D Next game for however many wish.  Do not feel limited by ideas, and if you wish use the FB group or these comments to discuss your contributions.

We are a donation based group so any contribution is appreciated.  Supplies, space, and website fees must be paid for, and your generous contributions help us grow and offer even better events in the future!  If you're interested in finding out where the money goes please take a look at the 'Money' tab under group tools.

Dawn Rite 7:15(ish) AM

This rite is usually filled with giggles and mis-speaking, as some people are just too damned tired to do it right.  That is okay, the gods love mirth, and this is one of the classic rituals in which the gods laugh with you.  A new year has begun!  You spent some time this night contemplating your oaths, and here you release what holds you back and greet this new year with a strong spirit and pure intentions.

Optional post Dawn Rite breakfast.

Depending on the number of people, and schedules, we can arrange a community breakfast that morning.  Please discuss in the notes!

Please add in the comments if you plan on staying for the vigil.  It helps us plan.  Also, I suspect several people are coffee drinkers, and while we have a number of providers nearby, we need some overnight coffee machines, so please let us know.

Please also put in the comments what kind of dish you plan on bringing, so others may fill in the gaps.  Consider making something that people with food restrictions or food allergies can enjoy.

You are encouraged to bring your well tended children to our Yule celebration!
results.name: Yule Rite and Vigil (with a fun pajama party to boot)!

results.description:
$10.00 suggested gift value.

What is a White Elephant Gift Exchange?
White Elephant is a gift exchange game that is very similar in style to Yankee Swap, although the emphasis is to ‘steal’ gifts rather than swap them.
The game derives its name from the term white elephant as defined by something of dubious or limited value or an object no longer of value to its owner but of value to others. Thus, in its basic form the game calls for people to bring “gag” gifts or gifts they received that they have no use for.

In a White Elephant gift exchange each participant brings a wrapped, unmarked gift and places it in a designated area. Guests are given numbers as they arrive, or their names are randomly drawn, and they select gifts in that order — with a twist.

On the first turn, the person assigned with #1 picks out a gift and opens it so all can see what it is. On the second turn, the person assigned with #2 gets the choice of “stealing” #1’s unwrapped gift or choosing a wrapped one from the pile. If #2 steals #1’s gift, then #1 must choose and open a wrapped gift.

As subsequent players take their turns, they either select a new gift or take any already opened gift from any of the other players. Have any player who has a gift taken away either choose a new gift or take an already-opened gift from another player.

The game continues with the following rules:

If someone steals your gift, you can steal someone else’s gift or choose and open a wrapped one.

Continue until everyone has had a turn for a gift. A turn is ended when an unopened gift has been opened.

A gift can only be “stolen” once during a turn. If a gift is taken from someone during one round, she cannot take it back during that same round. She can, however, take it back in a later round if she is in a position to select a gift.

A gift cannot be immediately stolen back from the player who just stole it.

Once a gift has 3 “owners”, the 3rd owner of a gift gets to keep it – it is retired and can’t be stolen again.

The gift exchange ends when the last wrapped gift is chosen and opened.
After the last turn, the person who started (since she didn’t get a chance at the beginning) can put back the gift and “steal” a gift according to the rules. This starts the gift exchange again (following the above rules) and ends when someone chooses or is forced to take the gift given up by the person with #1.

-secretsanta.com
results.how_to_find_us: Call or text 410-804-7248 to enter.
results.name: White Elephant Gift Exchange

venue.name: corner of Loch Raven Drive and Morgan Mill Road

results.description:
One of the best kept secrets here just north of Towson is the public access to a "protected" area of Loch Raven Reservoir park on the weekend.  On both Saturday and Sunday, park police close off Loch Raven Drive (some maps call it Loch Raven Rd.) between Morgan Mill Road and Providence Road. The road becomes a recreational area for walking, running, biking, and the like.  In the warmer months, many people picnic or just relax on blankets and chairs along the water.  The views of the water and the surrounding wooded areas are wonderful all year round.

It is an "out and back" hike, can't possibly get lost, bite off as much as you want to chew.

The total distance is approximately 3 and 1/2 miles which we complete in roughly 1 hour, so that you can probably be home before noon, if you want to. But also feel free to stay as long as you like.

 Loch Raven is city reservoir property. It, technically, is not a park at all. In other words, no potty facilities, no pavilions, etc. What you see is what you get. So......take care of business before you get there.

To get there, if you are travelling north on Dulaney Valley Rd. from the Beltway, the road splits just after crossing a large bridge over the lake. Dulaney Valley Rd. is the one that continues to the right toward the east. That's what you want. Don't go up the hill which is Jarrettsville Pike.

Travel on Dulaney Valley Road for roughly another mile or so. You will enter the park from the north. To do so, you bear right/make a right hand turn from Dulaney Valley Rd onto Loch Raven Drive at the corner where Peerce's Plantation/Landing/Grille (the name depends on who owns it this week; it's had some turnover in recent years) is located.  Peerce's address is 12460 Dulaney Valley Road 21131. If your GPS is telling you to go farther north on Dulaney Valley Rd past Peerce's, it's just plain wrong !!! Once you enter the park, the meeting place is about a mile down the road.

This hike will begin at the road closure gate at the corner of Loch Raven Drive and Morgan Mill Road. Parking is allowed on the west side of Loch Raven Drive and there is a sort of a parking lot on Morgan Mill Road.

When you see this sign, you've found the right place.  We'll meet right behind it, by where you see the guy/rock. 

Loch Raven Drive is a normal, well paved road, so there is no need for "off road" footwear unless you choose to get adventurous and challenge the rather steep hills that surround the lake.  That is certainly an option for those who are more experienced and confident.  However, I am not aware of any sanctioned, prepared trails in that area of Loch Raven and can't recommend it.  It would be free style.

I will not post cancellations because of the weather. I assume we're all capable of making that decision as each of us sees fit.

If you decide to respond "Yes" to this event and later change your mind for whatever reason, please,please go in and change your RSVP to a "No". That way, we know not to be waiting for you. Thanks.

So come join us on Sunday for a brisk walk in the park. It's a great way to clean out the cobwebs and start a Sunday.
results.how_to_find_us: Please read the directions below carefully. We do NOT meet at Peerce's. That's just a landmark along the way.
results.name: Loch Raven Beginner Hike

results.description:
It is true that the golden rule is to treat others how we wish to be treated ourselves. This is a great beginning for developing societies and communities that value the right of every individual to have the opportunity to thrive.

Love is the key to taking that idea one step farther. If we Love everyone we may even treat them in ways that we would hope for others to treat us that exceed common courtesy. We may even find ourselves being willing to share more, help more, care more, get more involved and be more active in supporting our fellow neighbors if we were to imagine the synergy of being willing to do these things and being surrounded by people willing to Love in this same way.

When we open ourselves to Love our neighbors we create a neighborhood founded in Love. This is how people go beyond letting each other live and let live and get into living in Love with each other.

Our speaker this week is Reverend Brian Akers, Senior Minister of the Columbia Center for Spiritual Living.  Come to this Meetup and see if CCSL is the spiritual community that you have been looking for.
results.how_to_find_us: 6175 Sunny Spring, Columbia, MD 21044
results.name: Sunday Experience

results.description:
Frank will briefly share personal experiences attempting to integrate human rights concerns into U.S. foreign policy in two challenging countries: China and North Korea. He will talk about what worked, and what didn’t, when he was on Capitol Hill working for Senators Biden and Kerry and when he was at Amnesty International. He will also try to convey a sense of how human rights sometimes get shunted aside by U.S. policy makers focused on other priorities – usually national security and trade. He will speak a bit about what grassroots activists can accomplish, based on his time at Amnesty International. He hopes the talk will stimulate our thinking about what we can do as citizens to advance human rights far from our shores, even though he knows and appreciates that there is much that needs to be done right here in Baltimore.

Speaker Bio: Frank Jannuzi joined the Mansfield Foundation as President and Chief Executive Officer in April 2014. The Mansfield Foundation is dedicated to promoting cooperation and understanding between the United States and the nations and peoples of East Asia. He previously served as Deputy Executive Director (Advocacy, Policy and Research) at Amnesty International, USA. There he shaped and promoted legislation and policies to advance universal human rights, protect individuals and communities at risk, and free prisoners of conscience. He has traveled throughout Asia and has written extensively on East Asia policy issues, including U.S. relations with Japan, China, and North Korea. He lives in Baltimore with his wife, Dr. Jennifer Martin, and their two daughters.
results.name: Sunday Platform: "Human Rights and U.S. East Asia Policy"

results.description:
Hike Avalon and Orange Grove Areas - Patapsco State Park - 7 Miles


We were really lucky this past weekend with two amazingly warm and beautiful December days to paddle.  The high this Saturday is going to be in the low 40's with winds around 15 MPH.  Sunday is going to be a little bit better but I still think it will be a better day for a hike than a paddle.

This is a very beautiful hike and will include some time along the Patapsco River, Cascade Falls (Pictured above by Mary Dalnekoff), the Swinging Bridge (Pictured below also by Mary) and another great small stream that I don't know the name of.

I should warn that this hike also includes a very short section where some people prefer to go butt schootchen instead of walking as in the picture below.  There's usually also a Christmas tree along our route that is decorated with ornaments brought by hikers who pass by at this time of year.  You may want to bring one of your own to leave.  Pack a lunch or a snack for a break somewhere around the mid point.  Be sure to brink plenty to drink to stay well hydrated.


I sometimes get lazy and don't send a details email for hike so pay attention to the directions above and please be on time.  We will hit the trail promptly at 10:30.

Downtown Historic Ellicott City is a short drive from the park and we frequently stop by there after the hike for a drink or a snack and to see it all dressed up for the holidays.
results.how_to_find_us: Drive all the way in to the park until you get to a T-intersection.  Turn LEFT and meet in the parking area a short distance on the RIGHT
results.name: Hike Avalon and Orange Grove Areas - Patapsco State Park - 7 Miles

results.description:
These trails are mostly non-technical with some semi-technical parts, some climbing and flowy downhills on the fire road & certain single track with some rooty areas, logs, and drop-offs. Depending on the dynamics of the group we are going to try for 10-15 miles. The ride is a no drop meaning that we will stop at intersections. Dress for the weather 42°. Helmet (no helmet, no ride). Mountain Bike shoes, Water, Snack, Multi-Tool (although you can borrow one) Patch Kit, Tube, etc.

Disclaimer: Mountain biking is a risky sport, By signing up for this meetup you are agreeing you have seen, read, and understand our waiver located here:http://www.meetup.com/MVD-Mountain-Bikers/pages/Standard_Waiver_for_Meetup_Rides/

results.description:
and Football!


It's a Potluck Luncheon!!    Also, since it is a Raven's game day, we will have the Ravens and Chiefs on the big screen! 

PLUS- ***Bring your best Christmas cookies!  We will have a blind cookie taste contest.  Bring cookie bites or we will cut the cookies into pieces so there can be a taste for everyone.  We will vote on our favorite for a prize!

***Jan will be bringing another get-to-know-you game!

 Bring food to share and join the group that is

"Singles With Grace"

at Grace Community Church

for their monthly potluck luncheon.

We eat, we socialize, we hang out and a few games might be played.

There is a lot of opportunity to mix, mingle, meet other singles and make friends at these monthly potlucks.  Jan usually has a icebreaker game to get us talking to one another.

We start gathering for the luncheon (setting up tables, chairs and such) around  12:45 PM with the goal of beginning to eat around 1:00 PM.

Directions and MAP (click link)

If you enter the church from the first parking lot that you come to, the Grace Place area is on the opposite side of the church.  Walk through the lobby to the opposite end and you will see Grace Place.  (You can also ask at one of the information desks.)  If you park around back of the church and enter through those doors, the Grace Place area will be on your left as you enter the building.

Bring a potluck dish to share.

A potluck dish is a substantial main dish, salad or side/dessert item.

Across the street from the church, there is a Harris Teeter grocery store and about 1/2 mile away at one of the traffic circles is a Food Lion grocery store.  This may be an option if you are coming from your church's worship service and need to pick up an item to contribute to the potluck.

You can also pick up take out food - a bucket of chicken or side items, a few sub sandwiches of $5 footlongs from Subway, a carry out order of chinese food - you don't have to cook....although delicious homemade casseroles and salads are much appreciated!!

Grace does not have refrigerators or microwaves (yet) that we can use to keep items cold or to heat them.  Kitchen is coming soon, we hope!

Usually there are 60 to 75 single men and women who regularly attend these monthly luncheons, both from Grace Community Church and from our Meetup group.

Check out some photos from previous luncheons - click the link below -

Outdoors:

PHOTOS FROM THE LUNCHEON ON JULY 17th

PHOTOS FROM THE LUNCHEON ON AUGUST 21st

Indoors:

PHOTOS FROM THE LUNCHEON ON DECEMBER 16th

PHOTOS FROM THE LUNCHEON ON NOVEMBER 18th

Note - This is the church that Michelle, Mike and Jan regularly attend.  Posting this event is in no way an attempt to take you away from your home church.  Please attend your church's worship service on Sunday morning and then join us for the luncheon.

If you do not have a regular church and/or want to use this as an opportunity to visit Grace, please contact one of us and we will coordinate with you to meet you in the lobby at 11:00 AM.

The Singles With Grace group normally sits together during the 11:15 service.  We sit about halfway down the far right section when facing the stage.  If you arrive after 11:15 and want to sit with us, look for the group in that area.

Website of Grace Community Church

CLICK LINK for Directions and MAP

DRIVING DIRECTIONS -- Don't rely solely on plugging the church's address into your GPS if you have never been to the church before.  Some GPS devices don't like this address or they find it on a section of Old Columbia Road where the church is NOT actually located.

Grace Community Church is located in Fulton, Maryland, between Baltimore and Washington, DC, south of Columbia, on Old Columbia Road off of MD 216 just west of US 29.

From Columbia
Take US Route 29 south to MD 216. Take MD 216 west. After you exit US 29, you will go through a traffic circle. Follow the signs to take MD 216 west. Proceed through a second traffic circle.  Go around a third traffic circle and exit to the right onto Old Columbia Road.  The church entrance is the first right.

From Baltimore
Take I-95 south to MD 216. Take MD 216 west, Exit 35B Scaggsville. In a little over 2 miles, go through a traffic circle and cross US 29. Proceed through two more traffic circles.  Go around the fourth traffic circle and exit to the right onto Old Columbia Road.  The church entrance is the first right.

From Washington, DC
Take I-95 north to MD 216. Take MD 216 west, Exit 35B Scaggsville. In a little over 2 miles, go through a traffic circle and cross US 29. Proceed through two more traffic circles.  Go around the fourth traffic circle and exit to the right onto Old Columbia Road.  The church entrance is the first right.

results.description:
1 P.M. to 2 P.M. .....Cooking class (We will be cooking an indian garbanzo bean dish).  Printout explaining the ingredients and cooking method will be given out.  In addition to that, you will get to see and participate in actually making the dish.

2 P.M. to 2:45 ......Potluck Lunch (Feel free to bring any dish that you'd like to share with the group.

3 P.M. to 4:30 P.M. ....Indian Folk Dance Instructions and practicing it.

Garba is an indian folk dance that originated in the state of Gujarat (west coast of India). It consists of dancing in a circle and with steps and claps that are coordinated.

The term “garba” is associated with the Sanskrit word “Garbha” meaning ‘womb”. The word also means light inside the earthen pot. The light represents life and the pot is the womb that carries this light. 

Raas is a folk dance also from Gujarat and is known in the west as "stick dance". 

The term "Raas" means "playful sweetness of life".  Immersing oneself in the dance and joy of earthly life. 

We will be teaching the basic steps of these dances and after about 1/2 hour of instructions, we'll be able to actually do this dance. 
It is a lot of fun so do come and join us! 
There is no charge for this event but we ask that you bring a snack to share with the group. 

Check out "garba" on youtube: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rA2JAlNEqRw 

Check out "Raas" on youtube:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=26GMtIBE5rE
results.name: Cooking class ~ Potluck Lunch ~ Learn Indian Folk Dance ~ (Free)
